{"uri": "8218270574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:08:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:08:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:07:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/tech-startup/news/microsoft-leaves-openai-board-3653451", "title": "Microsoft leaves OpenAI board", "body": "Microsoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company.\n\nMicrosoft has decided to leave its board observer seat at OpenAI, a position that has attracted regulatory scrutiny in both the United States and Europe. The company stated that this move was prompted by significant improvements in OpenAI's governance over the past eight months, rendering the observer seat unnecessary.\n\nApple, which last month announced bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said the company will establish a new engagement approach by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT. The seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the US over how much control it exerts over OpenAI. Microsoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement. In contrast, the British and US antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns. Additionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months, we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and US antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is {"uri": "2024-07-417285080", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:32:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:32:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:27:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/technology/artificial-intelligence/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny-9444619/", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny", "body": "Apple, which last month announced bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said the company will establish a new engagement approach by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417804116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:29:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:29:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.inc.com/reuters/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny.html", "title": "Microsoft Ditches OpenAI Board Observer Seat Amid Regulatory Scrutiny", "body": "Both Microsoft and Apple were expected to take observers board seats at the maker of ChatGPT, but have backed off, and plan to focus on meeting with OpenAI as stakeholders.\n\nMicrosoft has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\nApple, which last month announced bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said the company will establish a new engagement approach by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\nReporting by Foo Yun Chee; Additional reporting by Krystal Hu and Jeffrey Dastin in San Francisco and Nilutpal Timsina in Bangalore; Editing by Jamie Freed and Miral Fahmy. Copyright 2024. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8218598563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:32:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:32:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://kion546.com/money/cnn-business-consumer/2024/07/10/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny/", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- Microsoft has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company, which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the US over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and US antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8219060632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:22:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:22:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:22:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/companies/after-apple-microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amidst-regulatory-concerns-11720592811075.html", "title": "After Apple, Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amidst regulatory concerns | Mint", "body": "MICROSOFT-OPENAI:Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny\n\nBRUSSELS (Reuters) -Microsoft has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\nApple, which last month announced bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said the company will establish a new engagement approach by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\n(Reporting by Foo Yun Chee; Additional reporting by Krystal Hu and Jeffrey Dastin in San Francisco and Nilutpal Timsina in Bangalore; Editing by Jamie Freed and Miral Fahmy)", "source": {"uri": "livemint.com", {"uri": "8219265001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:11:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:11:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:11:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://ciso.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/next-gen-tech/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny/111639886", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny - ET CISO", "body": "Microsoft has given up its seat as a board observer position at OpenAI, which has attracted regulatory attention in both the UK and the US, citing the AI startup's marked governance improvements over the last eight months.\n\nApple recently announced plans to integrate OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT into its devices, would also not take an observer role on OpenAI's board, despite earlier expectations.\n\nOpenAI would instead host regular meetings with partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures. This is part of \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners\" under Sarah Friar, the former Nextdoor boss hired as its first chief financial officer last month, an OpenAI spokesperson said.\n\nIn November last year, Microsoft assumed a non-voting observer role on OpenAI's board after CEO Sam Altman resumed the company's leadership, which oversees the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThis position allowed Microsoft to attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but did not grant voting rights, particularly regarding the election or selection of directors. The tech giant also invested more than $10 billion in OpenAI.\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence,\" Microsoft's deputy general counsel Keith Dolliver wrote in a letter to OpenAI late on Tuesday.\n\nSince then \"we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\" Therefore, Microsoft's role on the board was no longer \"necessary\", he said.\n\nThe move also comes as antitrust authorities in the EU and US examine the partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI as part of broader concerns about competition in the rapidly growing sector.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are ramping up competition in selling AI technology to enterprise customers, seeking to bolster revenue and showcase their independence to regulators amidst ongoing antitrust scrutiny.\n\nMoreover, Microsoft is broadening its AI portfolio on the Azure platform and has appointed Inflection's CEO to lead its consumer AI division, seen as a strategic move to diversify beyond its reliance on OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": "ciso.economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-417637435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:32:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:32:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:07:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/finance/companies/microsoft-openai-board/2024/07/10/id/1171920/", "title": "Microsoft Ditches OpenAI Board Seat to Avoid Scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft has ditched its board observer seat at OpenAI in a move aimed at easing U.S. and UK antitrust regulators' concern about the extent of its control over the AI startup amid the soaring popularity of generative artificial intelligence.\n\nBut the move was unlikely to resolve concerns by the U.S. Federal Trade commission, a source at the agency said on Wednesday, which is conducting an antitrust review of deals by Big Tech firms and top AI companies.\n\nMeanwhile, Apple, which last month said it was bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, will not take an observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said the company would establish a new approach to engaging with stakeholders by hosting regular meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple, and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company.\n\nThe seat meant Microsoft could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in the European Union, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nThe position provided insights into the board's work without compromising its independence, Microsoft said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nIt cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation, and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup as reasons for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in the letter.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft is making a smart move by dropping the one tangible evidence of possible control over OpenAI, making it harder for antitrust regulators on both sides of the Atlantic to prove otherwise, said an antitrust lawyer who declined to be named due to the sensitivity of the matter.\n\nBritain's Competition and Markets Authority declined to comment.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, {"uri": "8219203761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:16:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:16:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/tech-news/what-microsoft-leaving-board-seat-at-chatgpt-maker-openai-means-for-apple/articleshow/111641931.cms", "title": "What Microsoft leaving board seat at ChatGPT maker OpenAI means for Apple - Times of India", "body": "In a sudden move, Microsoft announced its exit from ChatGPT maker OpenAI's board. Microsoft held an observer role on OpenAI's board. The company informed OpenAI the same in a letter. Microsoft has invested $13 billion in OpenAI. The company has been integrating OpenAI's tech across its Windows portfolio.\n\nPost Microsoft announcement, OpenAI spokesperson said that the startup won't have board observers after Microsoft's departure.There were reports that Apple was due to take up a similar role as Microsoft in OpenAI. At its recent annual developers conference, WWDC2024, Apple announced an AI partnership with OpenAI. Apple would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November 2023 after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired unceremoniously. He was taken back just hours later in a management reshuffle that also saw board shakeup. The seat meant that Microsoft could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including selecting or choosing directors. Apple joining the board would have meant the same rights for the iPhone maker.\n\n\"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement to Bloomberg News. Apple's partnership with OpenAI brings ChatGPT to iPhones.\n\nWhat's behind Microsoft giving up board seat\n\nMicrosoft has relinquished its board seat after regulatory pressure in Europe and the US. Last month, European Union (EU) antitrust regulators said that the partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nThe British and US antitrust watchdogs too continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence. In January, the US Federal Trade Commission said it was looking into Microsoft's investment in OpenAI as part of a broader inquiry into Big Tech companies and their partnerships with AI startups.\n\nThe TOI Tech Desk is a dedicated team of journalists committed to delivering the latest and most relevant news from the world of technology to readers of The Times of India. TOI Tech Desk's news coverage spans a wide spectrum across gadget launches, gadget reviews, trends, in-depth analysis, exclusive reports and breaking stories that impact technology and the digital universe. Be it how-tos or the latest happenings in AI, cybersecurity, personal gadgets, platforms like WhatsApp, Instagram, Facebook and more; TOI Tech Desk brings the news with accuracy and authenticity.", {"uri": "2024-07-415601891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:00:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/chinese-developers-scramble-openai-blocks-000034209.html", "title": "Chinese developers scramble as OpenAI blocks access in China", "body": "Chinese developers scramble as OpenAI blocks access in China\n\nAmy Hawkins Senior China correspondent\n\n9 July 2024 at 2:00 am\n\nAt the World AI Conference in Shanghai last week, one of China's leading artificial intelligence companies, SenseTime, unveiled its latest model, SenseNova 5.5.\n\nThe model showed off its ability to identify and describe a stuffed toy puppy (wearing a SenseTime cap), offered feedback on a drawing of a rabbit, and instantly read and summarised a page of text. According to SenseTime, SenseNova 5.5 is comparable with GPT-4o, the flagship artificial intelligence model of the Microsoft-backed US company OpenAI.\n\nIf that wasn't enough to entice users, SenseTime is also giving away 50m free tokens - digital credits for using the AI - and says that it will deploy staff to help new clients migrate from OpenAI services to SenseTime's products for free.\n\nChinese attempts to lure domestic developers away from OpenAI - considered the market leader in generative AI - will now be a lot easier, after OpenAI notified its users in China that they would be blocked from using its tools and services from 9 July.\n\n\"We are taking additional steps to block API traffic from regions where we do not support access to OpenAI's services,\" an OpenAI spokesperson told Bloomberg last month.\n\nOpenAI has not elaborated about the reason for its sudden decision. ChatGPT is already blocked in China by the government's firewall, but until this week developers could use virtual private networks to access OpenAI's tools in order to fine-tune their own generative AI applications and benchmark their own research. Now the block is coming from the US side.\n\nRising tensions between Washington and Beijing have prompted the US to restrict the export to China of certain advanced semiconductors that are vital for training the most cutting-edge AI technology, putting pressure on other parts of the AI industry.\n\nThe OpenAI move has \"caused significant concern within China's AI community\" said Xiaohu Zhu, the founder of the Shanghai-based Centre for Safe AGI, which promotes AI safety, not least because \"the decision raises questions about equitable access to AI technologies globally\".\n\nBut it has also created an opportunity for domestic AI companies such as SenseTime, which are scrambling to hoover up OpenAI's rejected users. After warnings about OpenAI's decision circulated last month, Baidu offered 50m free tokens for its Ernie 3.5 AI model, as well as free migration services, while Zhipu AI, another local company, offered 150m free tokens for its model. Tencent Cloud is giving away 100m free tokens for its AI model to new users until the end of July. \"Competitors are offering migration pathways for former OpenAI users, seeing this as an opportunity to expand their user base,\" said Zhu.\n\nOne consequence of OpenAI's decision may be that it accelerates the development of Chinese AI companies, which are in tight competition with their US rivals, as well as each other. China is estimated to have at least 130 large language models, accounting for 40% of the world's total and second only to the US. But while US companies such as OpenAI have been at the cutting edge of generative AI, Chinese companies have been engaged in a price war that some analysts have speculated may harm their profit margins and their ability to innovate. Still, Winston Ma, a professor at New York University who writes about Chinese technology, said OpenAI's departure from China comes \"at a time when Chinese big tech players are closing on performance gap with OpenAI and are offering these Chinese LLM models essentially free\".\n\n\"OpenAI's departure is a short-term shock to the China market, but it may provide a long-term opportunity for Chinese domestic LLM models to be put to the real test,\" said Ma. Until now, Chinese companies have focused on the commercialisation of large language models rather than advancing the models themselves, he added.\n\nChinese commentators have been keen to brush off the impact of OpenAI's decision. State media outlet the Global Times said it was \"a push from the US to hamper China's technology development\". Pan Helin, a digital economy researcher at Zhejiang University who sits on a government technology committee, described the development as \"a good thing for China's large-scale model independence and self-reliance\", according to Chinese media.\n\nBut there are signs that the US restrictions on China's AI industry are starting to bite. The online video giant Kuaishou recently had to restrict the number of people who could access its new text-to-video AI model, Kling, because of a lack of computing capacity caused by a shortage of chips, according to a report in The Information. And there is now a booming hidden market for US semiconductors, as companies find ways to circumvent the sanctions. Being blocked from US software may inspire similar creativity.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8219128123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:14:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:14:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:14:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/uncategorized/microsoft-quits-openai-board-seat-as-antitrust-scrutiny-of-artificial-intelligence-pacts-intensifies/", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board seat as antitrust scrutiny of artificial intelligence pacts intensifies - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nMicrosoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being roiled by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a Tuesday letter, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately,\" from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise departure comes amid intensifying scrutiny from antitrust regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested $13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's antitrust rules, while the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the pact.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind the ouster were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nIt's not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI startups, said Alex Haffner, a competition partner at U.K. law firm Fladgate.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to update stakeholders on progress and ensure stronger collaboration on safety and security.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelcolorado.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel Colorado"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8218829244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:51:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:51:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:51:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.silicon.co.uk/ai/microsoft-apple-drop-openais-board-seats-amid-antitrust-probe-571001", "title": "Microsoft, Apple Drop OpenAI's Board Seats | Silicon UK", "body": "Antitrust manoeuvring? Both Apple and Microsoft drop their respective observer seats on OpenAI's board of directors\n\nTwo big names in the tech industry, Apple and Microsoft, have taken a step back from their respective involvements with OpenAI's board of directors.\n\nThe Financial Times reported that Microsoft has given up its seat as an observer on the board at OpenAI. Meanwhile Apple will reportedly not take up a similar position on the board.\n\nMicrosoft has occupied an observer position on OpenAI's board ever since Microsoft made clear its displeasure with the previous not-for-profit board, which in November 2023 had unexpectedly fired CEO Sam Altman.\n\nObserver positions\n\nDays later, and under intense pressure from Microsoft, OpenAI had rehired Sam Altman after Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella had called for a \"change\" in the governance of OpenAI.\n\nWhen Sam Altman was reinstated as CEO, a new board of directors was also appointed, with Microsoft taking an observer seat due to the fact that Redmond, is by far, OpenAI's biggest investor (up to $13 billion).\n\nOpenAI also heavily depends on Microsoft's Azure cloud infrastructure for its costly computing infrastructure.\n\nMeanwhile it emerged last week that Apple fellow Phil Schiller, the iPhone maker's former marketing chief, was to given an observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nSchiller's appointment was due to Apple announcing at its annual WWDC developer conference, that it would bring OpenAI's ChatGPT chatbot to its devices including iPads, iPhones, Vision Pro headsets and Macs later this year.\n\nBoard withdrawal\n\nBut now the Financial Times has reported that Microsoft has given up its seat as an observer on the board of OpenAI while Apple will not take up a similar position.\n\nMicrosoft reportedly said in a letter to OpenAI that its withdrawal from its board role would be \"effective immediately\".\n\nApple had also been expected to take an observer role on OpenAI's board as part of a deal to integrate ChatGPT into the iPhone maker's devices, the FT reported, but would not do so, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.\n\nRead also : Keepler, Databricks Partner To Develop Intelligent Data Platforms\n\nApple declined to comment on the matter, the FT reported.\n\nInstead OpenAI will host regular meetings with partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures - part of \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners\" under Sarah Friar, the former Nextdoor boss who was hired as its first chief financial officer last month, an OpenAI spokesperson was quoted as saying.\n\nRegulatory pressure\n\nThe Microsoft retreat from governance oversight of OpenAI's board of directors comes as antitrust authorities in both the EU and US examine the partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI as part of broader concerns about competition in the rapidly growing AI sector.\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence,\" Microsoft's deputy general counsel Keith Dolliver was quoted by AP as writing in a letter to OpenAI late on Tuesday.\n\nSince then \"we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\" Therefore, Microsoft's role on the board was no longer \"necessary\", he reportedly added.\n\nOpenAI remains one of Microsoft's \"most valued partners\", Dolliver wrote.\n\nMicrosoft does not have a conventional equity stake in OpenAI. Instead, it has an entitlement to a share of the profits from a subsidiary of OpenAI, up to a certain limit.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson reportedly said: \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nOpenAI's eight-person board of directors includes Altman as well as Larry {"uri": "2024-07-417431453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:37:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:37:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.citizentribune.com/news/business/microsoft-quits-openai-board-seat-as-antitrust-scrutiny-of-artificial-intelligence-pacts-intensifies/article_fdb3586d-8ba3-5bdb-bc80-52e7b016b307.html", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board seat as antitrust scrutiny of artificial intelligence pacts intensifies", "body": "Microsoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being roiled by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a Tuesday letter, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately,\" from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise departure comes amid intensifying scrutiny from antitrust regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested $13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's antitrust rules, while the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the pact.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind the ouster were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nIt's not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI startups, said Alex Haffner, a competition partner at U.K. law firm Fladgate.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to {"uri": "8219056239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:19:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:19:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.thurrott.com/?p=305312", "title": "Microsoft and Apple Drop OpenAI Board Seats to Avoid Regulatory Scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft has ditched its observer seat on the OpenAI board as the company is facing regulatory scrutiny over its investments in the ChatGPT maker and other AI startups. Apple, which was also expected to get an observer role on the OpenAI board for veteran Phil Schiller has ultimately declined this opportunity, according to a new report from the Financial Times.\n\nIn a letter sent to OpenAI yesterday and seen by Axios, Microsoft justified its decision to give up its observer seat on OpenAI's board by the fact that it was no longer necessary. Dee Templeton, a vice president for technology and research partnerships and operations at Microsoft joined OpenAI's reconstituted board earlier this year after the previous board had fired and then rehired OpenAI CEO Sam Altman.\n\n\"As you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board,\" Microsoft said in the letter. \"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change. Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\nIn a statement shared with The Verge, OpenAI spokesperson Steve Sharpe explained how the company plans to keep its biggest partners and investors involved in its strategic decisions going forward. This will happen through \"regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nIn recent years, Microsoft invested over $10 billion into OpenAI, which is now using the Microsoft Azure cloud to develop and run its AI models at a global scale. Microsoft also obtained an exclusive license on OpenAI's GPT-4 models, and the company's close relationship with the ChatGPT makers led regulators in the US, the UK, and the EU to investigate.\n\nApple's situation is quite different as it's a latecomer to the generative AI race. Apple will reportedly not pay OpenAI any money for integrating ChatGPT into Apple Intelligence later this year, and the company said that it's looking to integrate more third-party AI models into its personal intelligence system. {"uri": "8218632886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:52:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:52:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:51:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://news.abplive.com/technology/microsoft-to-no-longer-hold-observer-seat-on-openai-board-amid-regulatory-concerns-1701676", "title": "Microsoft To No Longer Hold Observer Seat On OpenAI Board Amid Regulatory Concerns", "body": "Microsoft has decided to relinquish its observer seat on OpenAI's board in a move to alleviate regulatory concerns. This decision comes after notable improvements in OpenAI's governance over the past eight months, reported Reuters. In November 2023, Microsoft assumed a non-voting observer role on OpenAI's board, enabling it to attend meetings and access confidential information without influencing decisions. This move coincided with Sam Altman's return as CEO of OpenAI, the company known for its generative AI chatbot, ChatGPT.\n\nMicrosoft's substantial investment of over $10 billion in OpenAI had raised antitrust alarms in Europe, Britain, and the United States regarding the extent of its control over the AI startup.\n\nThe Financial Times reported that Apple, which recently announced the integration of ChatGPT into its devices, was anticipated to take on the observer role but has decided against it. Apple has not provided any comments on this matter, as per Reuters.\n\nAccording to Reuters, an OpenAI spokesperson revealed that the company plans to adopt a new engagement strategy, involving regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple, along with investors like Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new collaborations, innovative strides, and expanding customer base as reasons for stepping down from the observer position. In a letter dated July 9, Microsoft expressed confidence in OpenAI's direction, stating, \"Over the past eight months, we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this, we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWhile EU regulators have stated that Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI does not fall under the bloc's merger regulations, they will seek third-party input on the exclusivity clauses within the agreement. Meanwhile, British and US antitrust authorities continue to scrutinise Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the startup's autonomy.\n\nAs competition to provide AI technology to enterprise customers heats up, Microsoft and OpenAI are striving to prove their independence and address regulatory concerns. Microsoft is also broadening its AI capabilities on its Azure platform and has appointed the CEO of Inflection to lead its consumer AI division, indicating a strategic move to diversify beyond {"uri": "8216028244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:05:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:05:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:04:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/09/chinese-developers-openai-blocks-access-in-china-artificial-intelligence", "title": "Chinese developers scramble as OpenAI blocks access in China", "body": "US firm's move, amid Beijing-Washington tensions, sparks rush to lure users to homegrown models\n\nAt the World AI Conference in Shanghai last week, one of China's leading artificial intelligence companies, SenseTime, unveiled its latest model, SenseNova 5.5.\n\nThe model showed off its ability to identify and describe a stuffed toy puppy (wearing a SenseTime cap), offered feedback on a drawing of a rabbit, and instantly read and summarised a page of text. According to SenseTime, SenseNova 5.5 is comparable with GPT-4o, the flagship artificial intelligence model of the Microsoft-backed US company OpenAI.\n\nIf that wasn't enough to entice users, SenseTime is also giving away 50m free tokens - digital credits for using the AI - and says that it will deploy staff to help new clients migrate from OpenAI services to SenseTime's products for free.\n\nChinese attempts to lure domestic developers away from OpenAI - considered the market leader in generative AI - will now be a lot easier, after OpenAI notified its users in China that they would be blocked from using its tools and services from 9 July.\n\n\"We are taking additional steps to block API traffic from regions where we do not support access to OpenAI's services,\" an OpenAI spokesperson told Bloomberg last month.\n\nOpenAI has not elaborated about the reason for its sudden decision. ChatGPT is already blocked in China by the government's firewall, but until this week developers could use virtual private networks to access OpenAI's tools in order to fine-tune their own generative AI applications and benchmark their own research. Now the block is coming from the US side.\n\nRising tensions between Washington and Beijing have prompted the US to restrict the export to China of certain advanced semiconductors that are vital for training the most cutting-edge AI technology, putting pressure on other parts of the AI industry.\n\nThe OpenAI move has \"caused significant concern within China's AI community\" said Xiaohu Zhu, the founder of the Shanghai-based Centre for Safe AGI, which promotes AI safety, not least because \"the decision raises questions about equitable access to AI technologies globally\".\n\nBut it has also created an opportunity for domestic AI companies such as SenseTime, which are scrambling to hoover up OpenAI's rejected users. After warnings about OpenAI's decision circulated last month, Baidu offered 50m free tokens for its Ernie 3.5 AI model, as well as free migration services, while Zhipu AI, another local company, offered 150m free tokens for its model. Tencent Cloud is giving away 100m free tokens for its AI model to new users until the end of July. \"Competitors are offering migration pathways for former OpenAI users, seeing this as an opportunity to expand their user base,\" said Zhu.\n\nOne consequence of OpenAI's decision may be that it accelerates the development of Chinese AI companies, which are in tight competition with their US rivals, as well as each other. China is estimated to have at least 130 large language models, accounting for 40% of the world's total and second only to the US. But while US companies such as OpenAI have been at the cutting edge of generative AI, Chinese companies have been engaged in a price war that some analysts have speculated may harm their profit margins and their ability to innovate. Still, Winston Ma, a professor at New York University who writes about Chinese technology, said OpenAI's departure from China comes \"at a time when Chinese big tech players are closing on performance gap with OpenAI and are offering these Chinese LLM models essentially free\".\n\n\"OpenAI's departure is a short-term shock to the China market, but it may provide a long-term opportunity for Chinese domestic LLM models to be put to the real test,\" said Ma. Until now, Chinese companies have focused on the commercialisation of large language models rather than advancing the models themselves, he added.\n\nChinese commentators have been keen to brush off the impact of OpenAI's decision. State media outlet the Global Times said it was \"a push from the US to hamper China's technology development\". Pan Helin, a digital economy researcher at Zhejiang University who sits on a government technology committee, described the development as \"a good thing for China's large-scale model independence and self-reliance\", according to Chinese media.\n\nBut there are signs that the US restrictions on China's AI industry are starting to bite. The online video giant Kuaishou recently had to restrict the number of people who could access its new text-to-video AI model, Kling, because of a lack of computing capacity caused by a shortage of chips, according to a report in The Information. And there is now a booming hidden market for US semiconductors, as companies find ways to circumvent the sanctions. Being blocked from US software may inspire similar creativity.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "amy_hawkins@theguardian.com", {"uri": "8218756343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:07:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:07:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:07:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.windowscentral.com/microsoft/microsoft-steps-back-from-openai-board-will-no-longer-hold-observer-seat", "title": "Microsoft steps back from OpenAI board, will no longer hold observer seat", "body": "OpenAI and Microsoft will continue to work closely together, and Microsoft remains a significant shareholder in OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft no longer holds a seat on the board of OpenAI. Until recently, the tech giant held a non-voting observer seat on the OpenAI board. Axios and The Financial Times reported on a letter written to OpenAI by Microsoft Deputy General Counsel Keith Dolliver that announced the move. The Verge then received confirmation from OpenAI that Microsoft had given up its seat on the OpenAI board.\n\n\"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" said an OpenAI spokesperson to The Verge. \"Under the leadership of CFO Sarah Friar, we are establishing a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners - such as Microsoft and Apple - and investors - such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\"\n\nWhile Microsoft will not have a seat on OpenAI's board, the tech giant will be kept up to date of what's going on through \"regular stakeholder meetings.\"\n\nMicrosoft's relationship with OpenAI is complicated and storied. OpenAI exclusively partners with OpenAI for the cloud. That partnership came as part of an investment by Microsoft of over $10 billion. Microsoft has integrated OpenAI tech into a wide range of its services, including Copilot and Bing. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said AI tools would be built into all Microsoft products back in January 2023. Since then, several services have been infused with AI tech, often from OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft ended up with a non-voting seat on the OpenAI board after a dramatic few days that saw OpenAI co-founder and CEO forced out of the company, though Altman later returned. Microsoft was reportedly furious when blindsided by Altman's firing. The tech giant gaining a non-voting seat on the OpenAI board was viewed, at least in part, as a way to prevent future surprises.\n\nAxios shared contents of the letter written by Microsoft:\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision...\n\nAs you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board. This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change.\n\nOver the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\n\nGiven all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nBased on Microsoft's comments, it appears the company is content with OpenAI's current board.\n\nMicrosoft giving up its non-voting seat on the OpenAI board may also help Microsoft better face scrutiny from regulators. The FTC is looking into Microsoft's relationship with OpenAI. Having more formal separation between the companies could help convince the FTC that the two entities are sufficiently separate.", "source": {"uri": "windowscentral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8218477142", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:16:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:16:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:16:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://readwrite.com/microsoft-openai-board-observer-seat/", "title": "Microsoft gives up OpenAI board observer seat role", "body": "OpenAI will now engage partners like Microsoft and Apple through regular meetings under CFO Sarah Friar's guidance.\n\nMicrosoft has announced it will relinquish its observer seat on OpenAI's board. In a letter, the tech giant expressed that over the past eight months, there has been \"significant progress\" and it now has \"confidence in the company's direction,\" stating the observer seat \"no longer necessary.\"\n\nThis move comes after Microsoft assumed a non-voting, observer position on the board in November of the previous year when OpenAI CEO Sam Altman reassumed control of the company, which is known for operating the AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nDespite expectations, Apple has also opted not to take up the observer role on OpenAI's board. The decision was cited in a report by the Financial Times, which referenced a source directly familiar with the situation. This follows Apple's recent announcement to integrate OpenAI's ChatGPT into its devices.\n\nInstead of traditional board roles, OpenAI is shifting towards a different model of engagement with its partners. According to an OpenAI spokesperson, under the guidance of the newly appointed chief financial officer Sarah Friar, the company will conduct regular meetings with its key partners instead. This includes Microsoft and Apple, as well as investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said: \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nThe initiative was described as \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners.\"\n\nIn the letter, Microsoft stated: \"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision.\n\n\"As you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board.\"\n\nThe company said the position provided insights into the board's activities \"without compromising its independence,\" adding that it \"appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change.\"\n\nIt added: \"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" Microsoft said.\n\nLast month, EU antitrust regulators determined that the partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI would not fall under the bloc's merger regulations, as Microsoft does not control OpenAI. Instead, the regulators plan to solicit opinions from third parties regarding the exclusivity clauses included in the agreement. In December, the United Kingdom's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) also announced it was investigating the collaboration.", "source": {"uri": "readwrite.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8219045890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:17:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:17:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:12:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/11/business/foreign-business/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny/1956485", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny", "body": "BRUSSELS -- Microsoft has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the artificial intelligence (AI) startup's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\nApple, which last month announced bringing OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT to its devices, would not take the observer role on OpenAI's board after being widely expected to do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.An OpenAI spokesman said the company will establish a new engagement approach by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple, and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.Microsoft took a nonvoting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.The seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.The observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10-billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the United States over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.Microsoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\"Over the past eight months, we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this, we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.European Union antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.In contrast, the British and US antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.Microsoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.Additionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered {"uri": "2024-07-417500239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:34:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:34:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:27:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.in/tech/news/microsoft-and-apple-may-be-playing-the-long-game-by-ditching-openai-board-roles/articleshow/111637565.cms", "title": "Microsoft and Apple may be playing the long game by ditching OpenAI board roles | Business Insider India", "body": "Microsoft and Apple might have made a play to assuage antitrust regulators over their involvement with OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft has now relinquished its role as an observer on OpenAI's board, while Apple will not take up a similar spot, according to reports by outlets including The Financial Times.\n\nAlthough Microsoft had no voting rights, its decision may be a bid to ease the concerns of regulators, who have been trying to assess its influence over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft won an observer role following the brief ousting of Sam Altman as OpenAI's CEO last November.\n\nBut late Tuesday the company said it was not \"necessary\" to keep its seat after witnessing \"significant progress\" in the past eight months, according to a letter Microsoft sent to OpenAI seen by outlets including Axios and the Financial Times.\n\nMicrosoft also said in the letter that it's \"confident\" about OpenAI's \"direction.\"\n\nAlex Haffner, a competition partner at law firm Fladgate, told BI: \"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny of its (and other major tech players) influence over emerging AI players such as OpenAI.\"\n\nHe added: \"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of interrelationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward.\"\n\nMicrosoft has invested billions in the ChatGPT maker and gets nearly half of OpenAI's profits as part of the partnership deal. OpenAI still relies on Microsoft's cloud services for the computing power needed to train and run its large language models (LLMs).\n\nNew approach\n\nThe partnership has been considered to have given Microsoft a leg up in the AI race, as OpenAI's models power its AI features such as Copilot.\n\nAn OpenAI representative told BI that its new CFO, Sarah Friar, was taking a new approach to engaging with partners such as Microsoft and Apple, and investors including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\n\"Moving forward, we will host regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security,\" they said.\n\nApple is set to follow Microsoft's lead, retreating from its plan to take on a similar board observer role, the FT reported. Bloomberg previously reported that Apple had secured an observer seat.\n\nAntitrust scrutiny\n\nThis came after Apple announced it struck a partnership with OpenAI at its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in June, integrating ChatGPT into its devices including the iPhone as part of a broader AI push.\n\nThe pullback underscores the mounting antitrust scrutiny of Big Tech's grip on AI. Regulators in both the US and UK have raised concerns about potential market control through strategic partnerships.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are both facing regulatory scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission and the UK's Competition and Markets Authority. European regulators have also been assessing the partnership.\n\nIt remains to be seen whether Microsoft and Apple's moves will placate those concerns about their involvement with OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-417442512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:46:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:46:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:46:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.quiverquant.com/news/Microsoft%20Relinquishes%20OpenAI%20Board%20Seat%20", "title": "Microsoft Relinquishes OpenAI Board Seat", "body": "Microsoft (MSFT) has relinquished its board observer seat at OpenAI, citing significant improvements in the AI start-up's governance over the past eight months. This move comes amidst ongoing regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic. Apple, which recently announced plans to integrate OpenAI's ChatGPT into its devices, has also opted not to take up the observer role, contrary to previous expectations. Apple did not comment on the decision.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson revealed that the company plans to adopt a new engagement strategy by hosting regular stakeholder meetings with strategic partners such as Microsoft and Apple, as well as investors like Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures. Microsoft had initially taken a non-voting observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year, following CEO Sam Altman's return to the company. This position allowed Microsoft to attend board meetings and access confidential information without voting rights on significant decisions.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's substantial $10 billion investment in OpenAI have raised concerns among antitrust authorities in Europe, Britain, and the U.S. regarding Microsoft's potential control over OpenAI. In a letter dated July 9, Microsoft stated that due to OpenAI's new partnerships, innovations, and expanding customer base, it no longer deemed the observer role necessary. \"Over the past eight months, we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter read.\n\nWhile EU antitrust regulators have decided that the partnership does not fall under the bloc's merger rules, they continue to seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses within the agreement. In contrast, British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs remain concerned about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI. Both companies are striving to demonstrate their independence and mitigate regulatory concerns by expanding their AI offerings and competing for enterprise customers. Microsoft is also broadening its AI capabilities on the Azure platform and has appointed Inflection's CEO to lead its consumer AI division, signaling efforts to diversify beyond OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": "8218637099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:54:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:54:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:54:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.zerohedge.com/technology/microsoft-apple-abruptly-drop-openai-board-observer-seats-antitrust-investigations-mount", "title": "Microsoft & Apple Abruptly Drop OpenAI Board Observer Seats As Antitrust Investigations Mount", "body": "There's definitely more to this story than meets the eye.\n\nLet's begin with new details from the Financial Times, which reveal that Microsoft has relinquished its board observer seat at OpenAI, while Apple is not expected to take an observer role on the board.\n\nThe big mystery is why Microsoft and Apple are suddenly trying to distance themselves from OpenAI. Could it be due to mounting antitrust investigations from Europe to the US?\n\nHere's more from FT:\n\nMicrosoft, which has invested $13bn in the maker of the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT, said in a letter to OpenAI that its withdrawal from its board role would be \"effective immediately\".\n\nApple had also been expected to take an observer role on OpenAI's board as part of a deal to integrate ChatGPT into the iPhone maker's devices, but would not do so, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.\n\nInstead of the board observer seats, an OpenAI spokesperson said the startup plans to host regular meetings with partners, including Microsoft and Apple, and investors Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nThe spokesperson said this is \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners\" under Sarah Friar, the former Nextdoor boss who was recently hired as its first CFO.\n\nThe move comes as antitrust officials across the West, primarily in Europe and the US, scrutinize Microsoft and OpenAI's partnership amid major concerns about competition in the AI space.\n\nLast year, Microsoft accepted the observer board seat following the chaotic mess after chief executive Sam Altman was fired and then re-hired days later.\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence,\" Microsoft's deputy general counsel Keith Dolliver wrote in a letter to OpenAI late on Tuesday.\n\nDolliver continued by saying since then, \"We have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" and therefore, Microsoft's role on the board was no longer \"necessary.\"\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said: \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nIn June, the European Commission said it was exploring the possibility of an antitrust investigation between Microsoft and OpenAI. {"uri": "2024-07-417346909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:30:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.aol.com/microsoft-quits-openai-board-seat-103010975.html", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board seat as antitrust scrutiny of artificial intelligence pacts intensifies", "body": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board seat as antitrust scrutiny of artificial intelligence pacts intensifies\n\nKELVIN CHAN\n\nJuly 10, 2024 at 12:30 PM\n\nMicrosoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being roiled by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a Tuesday letter, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately,\" from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise departure comes amid intensifying scrutiny from antitrust regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested $13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's antitrust rules, while the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the pact.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind the ouster were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nIt's not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI startups, said Alex Haffner, a competition partner at U.K. law firm Fladgate.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to
