{"uri": "8219250230", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:58:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:58:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:57:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://siliconangle.com/2024/07/10/microsoft-apple-give-observer-seats-openais-board-amid-regulatory-scrutiny/", "title": "Microsoft, Apple give up observer seats on OpenAI's board amid regulatory scrutiny - SiliconANGLE", "body": "Microsoft, Apple give up observer seats on OpenAI's board amid regulatory scrutiny\n\nMicrosoft Corp. and Apple Inc. have decided not to sit on OpenAI's board amid the regulatory scrutiny facing the ChatGPT developer, the Financial Times reported today.\n\nMicrosoft, OpenAI's largest investor, received an observer seat on its board last November. The cloud computing and software giant is said to have given up the role on Tuesday. Apple, for its part, was likewise expected to become a board observer but has reportedly reversed course.\n\nThe development comes at a time when OpenAI is facing scrutiny from antitrust regulators in both the US and the European Union. The artificial intelligence provider's partnership with Microsoft is reportedly a particular focus. Microsoft has provided OpenAI with about $13 billion worth of funding and cloud infrastructure in exchange for a share of its profits, as well as the possibility of a future 49% stake.\n\nIn early June, the Wall Street Journal reported that the Federal Trade Commission is looking into the companies' partnership. The FTC is reportedly concerned that Microsoft may have structured the deal to give it control of OpenAI without drawing regulatory attention. Later that month, the European Union's top competition official revealed that the bloc may launch a probe into the companies over \"certain exclusivity clauses\" in their partnership agreement.\n\nMicrosoft took an observer seat on OpenAI's board last December following the brief ouster of Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman. After Altman returned to the top post, the directors who had voted to fire him left the company and the board was restructured. Microsoft reportedly played a key role in securing Altman's reinstatement.\n\nKeith Dolliver, Microsoft's deputy general counsel, informed OpenAI of the company's plan to exit the board in a letter sent late Tuesday. \"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the executive wrote. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said that \"we're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nAbout a week before Microsoft's letter, Bloomberg cited sources as saying that Apple planned to take an observer seat on OpenAI's board. The iPhone maker was reportedly set to receive the position as part of a partnership it had announced with the AI developer in June. According to the Financial Times, the iPhone maker no longer plans to join the board.\n\nApple's collaboration with OpenAI will see it use ChatGPT to power parts of Apple Intelligence, an upcoming set of AI features for iPhones and Macs. Some of the ChatGPT-powered capabilities are set to become available in the iPhone maker's document and image editing tools. Others will be integrated into Siri to enhance the AI assistant's ability to answer user questions.", "source": {"uri": "siliconangle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SiliconANGLE"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-417388424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:59:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:59:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:58:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/microsoft-quits-openai-board-seat-as-antitrust-scrutiny-of-artificial-intelligence-pacts-intensifies/article_2b5a4bfc-579f-5c69-867c-72f08f9a9b9f.html", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board seat as antitrust scrutiny of artificial intelligence pacts intensifies", "body": "Microsoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being roiled by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a Tuesday letter, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately,\" from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise departure comes amid intensifying scrutiny from antitrust regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested $13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's antitrust rules, while the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the pact.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind the ouster were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nIt's not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI startups, said Alex Haffner, a competition partner at U.K. law firm Fladgate.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to {"uri": "8218595318", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:27:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:27:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:27:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-apple-ditch-openai-board-observer-seats-regulators-2024-7", "title": "Microsoft and Apple may be playing the long game by ditching OpenAI board roles", "body": "Microsoft won an observer role following the brief ousting of Sam Altman as OpenAI's CEO last November.\n\nBut late Tuesday the company said it was not \"necessary\" to keep its seat after witnessing \"significant progress\" in the past eight months, according to a letter Microsoft sent to OpenAI seen by outlets including Axios and the Financial Times.\n\nMicrosoft also said in the letter that it's \"confident\" about OpenAI's \"direction.\"\n\nAlex Haffner, a competition partner at law firm Fladgate, told BI: \"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny of its (and other major tech players) influence over emerging AI players such as OpenAI.\"\n\nHe added: \"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of interrelationships that Big Tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward.\"\n\nMicrosoft has invested billions in the ChatGPT maker and gets nearly half of OpenAI's profits as part of the partnership deal. OpenAI still relies on Microsoft's cloud services for the computing power needed to train and run its large language models (LLMs).\n\nThe partnership has been considered to have given Microsoft a leg up in the AI race, as OpenAI's models power its AI features such as Copilot.\n\nAn OpenAI representative told BI that its new CFO, Sarah Friar, was taking a new approach to engaging with partners such as Microsoft and Apple, and investors including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\n\"Moving forward, we will host regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security,\" they said.\n\nApple is set to follow Microsoft's lead, retreating from its plan to take on a similar board observer role, the FT reported. Bloomberg previously reported that Apple had secured an observer seat.\n\nThis came after Apple announced it struck a partnership with OpenAI at its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in June, integrating ChatGPT into its devices including the iPhone as part of a broader AI push.\n\nThe pullback underscores the mounting antitrust scrutiny of Big Tech's grip on AI. Regulators in both the US and UK have raised concerns about potential market control through strategic partnerships.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are both facing regulatory scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission and the UK's Competition and Markets Authority. European regulators have also been assessing the partnership.\n\nIt remains to be seen whether Microsoft and Apple's moves will placate those concerns about their involvement with OpenAI.", "source": {"uri": "8219169014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:47:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:47:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:47:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/apple-microsoft-give-up-openai-observer-seats/", "title": "Apple and Microsoft take a step back from OpenAI | Digital Trends", "body": "Digital Trends may earn a commission when you buy through links on our site. Why trust us?\n\nBarely a week after news broke that Apple Fellow Phil Schiller would join the OpenAI board in a non-voting observer role, Financial Times reports that the two companies are nixing that plan to avoid potential antitrust scrutiny.\n\nSchiller, who heads Apple's App store and Apple Events, as well as formerly served as the company's chief marketer, will instead reportedly receive regular meetings with the AI startup, along with other partners and investors, including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nOpenAI currently has an eight-member board that includes former U.S. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, and most recently, former National Security Agency (NSA) director Paul M. Nakasone. Per Bloomberg, the observer role \"allows someone to attend board meetings without being able to vote or exercise other director powers. Observers, however, do gain insights into how decisions are made at the company.\"\n\nSchiller was reportedly going to join the board in that capacity as the result of a potential AI partnership between the two companies wherein Apple would host OpenAI's models as part of its upcoming Apple Intelligence service.\n\nMicrosoft, OpenAI's biggest financial backer (which has invested more than $10 billion in the startup since 2023), was also previously offered a similar board position. However, as Axios reported Tuesday, Microsoft has reportedly seen \"significant progress\" from OpenAI in the months since Altman's attempted ouster last November, which prompted Microsoft's initial push for the position. As a result, it no longer sees the observer role as a necessity.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" Microsoft wrote in a letter shared with Axios. \"As you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board. This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change.\"\n\nBoth moves come as European and U.S. regulators intensify their investigations into potential antitrust violations surrounding Apple and Microsoft's dominant positions within the AI market, which could push out smaller firms and create monopoly conditions for these larger companies. Microsoft is already under investigation by U.S. regulators for its sizable investment into OpenAI, as well as by British competition regulators over the observer seat itself.\n\nIn response, an OpenAI representative told Financial Times, \"While our partnership with Microsoft includes a multibillion-dollar investment, OpenAI remains an entirely independent company governed by the OpenAI {"uri": "8218575097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:15:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:15:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:14:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/uncategorised/2024/07/10/microsoft-quits-openai-board-as-competition-scrutiny-of-ai-partnership-increases/", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board as competition scrutiny of AI partnership increases", "body": "Microsoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being rocked by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a letter on Tuesday, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately\", from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise move comes amid intensifying scrutiny from competition regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested 13 billion US dollars (\u00a310.2 billion) in OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI chief executive Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind his removal were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly-formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter.\n\n\"Given all of this, we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\nAlex Haffner, a competition partner at UK law firm Fladgate, said it is not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI start-ups.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to update stakeholders {"uri": "2024-07-417603938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:03:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:03:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:38:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/microsoft-drops-openai-board-seat-scrunity-increases-1849406", "title": "Microsoft Drops OpenAI Board Seat As Scrunity Increases", "body": "Microsoft has ditched plans to take up a non-voting position on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as regulators step up scrutiny of deals involving AI companies.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence the tech giant has over its smaller partner.\n\nIts early investment in OpenAI has made Microsoft a market leader in AI.\n\nWhen ChatGPT hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution as the chatbot dazzled users with its ability to churn out eloquent text in seconds.\n\nBut regulators began examining the partnership after a failed boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman -- whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nAfter the turmoil in OpenAI, Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", according to a letter sent from the company to OpenAI on Tuesday.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter stated.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe EU last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBrussels is however now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses\" could harm competition.\n\nMicrosoft is also under examination over its ties to OpenAI by British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\n\"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny,\" said Alex Haffner, a competition lawyer, at Fladgate law firm.\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nApple had been due to get a seat after partnering with OpenAI for a suite of new AI features on its popular devices -- rolling out soon in markets outside the EU.\n\nThe bloc's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nWith regulators focused on \"the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers\", lawyer Haffner said there was a \"need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward\".\n\nAnother phenomenon in the AI market in the EU's crosshairs is so-called \"acqui-hires\" -- when a company acquires another firm mainly to grab its key talent -- with Brussels racing to understand if it distorts competition.\n\nMicrosoft earlier this year announced a deal to hire senior figures from OpenAI rival Inflection, including its boss, to head up a newly created consumer AI unit.\n\nBut unlike a merger, Inflection still operates as an independent company and such a move by Microsoft means it avoids a traditional merger probe.\n\nRegulators have the right to block mergers if there are fears of Microsoft reportedly invested $13 billion in Altman's OpenAI, The Associated Press reported.\n\nAntitrust regulators at the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) are investigating OpenAI and Microsoft over their role in the rapidly growing AI industry.\n\nThe Biden administration has pushed for greater regulation of the AI industry, wary that top tech companies could quickly gain a stranglehold over the developing technology.\n\nThe FTC previously launched a similar investigation into Microsoft, Amazon and Google's investments in OpenAI and AI startup Anthropic in January.\n\nFTC Chair Lina Khan said at the time that the agency would scrutinize deals that \"enable dominant firms to exert undue influence or gain privileged access in ways that could undermine fair competition.\"", {"uri": "8218907973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:41:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:41:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:41:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.techtimes.com/articles/306554/20240710/apple-microsoft-abandon-openai-board-seats-amid-ai-regulatory-scrutiny.htm", "title": "Apple, Microsoft Abandon OpenAI Board Seats Amid AI Regulatory Scrutiny", "body": "Tech giants Apple and Microsoft have decided to forgo their observer seats on the board of OpenAI amid growing global regulatory scrutiny on companies offering artificial intelligence (AI) services.\n\nInitially, reports suggested that Apple's Phil Schiller would join OpenAI's board as an observer, a position tied to the recent integration of ChatGPT into Apple's iOS 18.\n\nHowever, Apple has now decided against this move. Instead, the company will hold regular meetings with OpenAI to discuss collaborative interests.\n\nThe Financial Times explains that this observer role would have granted Schiller a non-voting position at OpenAI's board meetings, providing Apple with insights into OpenAI's strategic plans without direct control.\n\nBy opting for regular meetings over a formal board position, Apple aims to sidestep any antitrust issues that might arise from having a seat on the board of a prominent AI company.\n\nMicrosoft, a major investor in OpenAI, has also given up its observer seat on the AI company's board.\n\nThis decision was communicated in a letter to OpenAI, stating that the withdrawal was effective immediately. Microsoft's involvement with OpenAI includes a massive $13 billion investment, crucial for OpenAI's access to computing power and cloud storage.\n\nThe observer role for Microsoft came into existence after a tumultuous period last year when OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman was abruptly fired by the board, only to be reinstated shortly after. This role allowed Microsoft to stay informed about board activities without compromising its independence.\n\nKeith Dolliver, Microsoft's deputy general counsel, explained in his letter that their position allowed them to gain insights into the board's activities while maintaining its independence.\n\nHe noted that since then, they have observed substantial progress from the newly established board and feel confident about the company's trajectory.\n\nRead Also: Apple Unveils iPhone 16 Pro Specs and AI Integration With Major Updates in Battery Tech and Messages App\n\nThe decisions by Apple and Microsoft come as antitrust authorities in the European Union and the United States intensify their scrutiny of Big Tech's investments in AI start-ups.\n\nThe European Commission has been exploring the possibility of an antitrust investigation into the partnership between Microsoft and OpenAI, while the US Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice have also begun examining these investments.\n\nIn response to these regulatory pressures, OpenAI has adopted a new approach to engaging with its strategic partners. Instead of board seats, the organization will now host regular meetings with key partners, including Microsoft, Apple, Thrive Capital, and Khosla Ventures.\n\nOpenAI's eight-member board continues to include influential figures such as Sam Altman, former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, and Instacart CEO Fidji Simo, with Bret Taylor, former co-CEO of Salesforce, serving as chairman.\n\nStay {"uri": "8219209535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:21:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:21:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:20:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/tech/microsoft-apple-drop-openai-board-plans-as-scrutiny-grows/articleshow/111642063.cms", "title": "Microsoft, Apple drop OpenAI board plans as scrutiny grows", "body": "Microsoft and Apple have decided against taking board roles at OpenAI, citing regulatory scrutiny. Microsoft's $13 billion investment and integration of OpenAI's tech in products like Windows face antitrust probes. Despite withdrawing, concerns about stifling competition persist. US and European regulators are scrutinizing Big Tech's dominance in AI. Analysts foresee AWS and Google becoming preferred partners amid growing demand and regulatory pressure. This move underscores challenges as tech giants balance innovation and regulatory compliance in the AI landscape.Microsoft Corp. and Apple Inc. dropped plans to take board roles at OpenAI in a surprise decision that underscores growing regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech's influence over artificial intelligence.\n\nMicrosoft, which invested $13 billion in the ChatGPT creator, will withdraw from its observer role on the board, the company said in a letter to OpenAI on Tuesday, which was seen by Bloomberg News. Apple was\n\ndue to take up a similar role, but an OpenAI spokesperson said the startup won't have board observers after Microsoft's departure.\n\nRegulators in the US and Europe had expressed concerns about Microsoft's sway over OpenAI, applying pressure on one of the world's most valuable companies to show that it's keeping the relationship at\n\narm's length. Microsoft has integrated OpenAI's services into its Windows and Copilot AI platforms and, like other big US tech companies, is banking on the new technology to help drive growth.\n\nStill, the board resignation is unlikely to resolve the US Federal Trade Commission's concerns about Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI, a source familiar with the agency's thinking said. Other regulators will\n\nlikely feel similarly because the change doesn't alter Microsoft's close ties to the startup, analysts at Bloomberg Intelligence said in a note on Wednesday.\n\n\"Microsoft 'giving up' its OpenAI board seat is just another gambit on the chessboard,\" said Foxglove director Cori Crider, whose law firm is pushing for more antitrust scrutiny of the relationship. \"Big Tech know they're in a cat-and-mouse game with antitrust enforcers over AI.\" The Financial Times reported Microsoft's exit earlier.\n\nWhat Bloomberg Intelligence Says:\n\nThe move by Microsoft and Apple to opt out as observers from the OpenAI board may be driven by regulatory pressure, but we don't see this lessening their influence over the latter's product strategy or ending\n\nthe antitrust investigations. In the longer term, we see other cloud providers such as AWS or even Google to be preferred vendors for OpenAI as demand increases and it faces more scrutiny globally.\n\n-- Justin Teresi, BI Litigation Analyst and Anurag Rana BI Technology\n\nAnalyst AI Scrutiny\n\nMicrosoft is facing broader scrutiny over its alleged dominance of artificial intelligence. In January, the US Federal Trade Commission said it was looking into Microsoft's investment in OpenAI as part of a\n\nbroader inquiry into Big Tech companies and their partnerships with AI startups. Separately, the US is looking at whether the company properly notified antitrust agencies about its deal with an OpenAI rival,\n\nInflection AI, people familiar with the matter have said.\n\nEuropean regulators also said they were going to survey Microsoft's rivals about OpenAI's exclusive use of its technology, and the UK's competition regulator is weighing a deeper investigation of the tie up.\n\nMicrosoft isn't being singled out. The UK is also looking into Amazon.com Inc.'s $4 billion collaboration with AI company Anthropic, expressing concern that large tech companies are using partnerships to \"shield themselves from competition.\" The US is probing Nvidia Corp.'s dominance over AI chips.\n\nMicrosoft shares rose 0.4% to $461.38 at 11:31 a.m. in New York trading. Apple gained 1.1% to $231.19.\n\nBig Tech Investments\n\nThe biggest US tech companies including Microsoft as well as Nvidia, Alphabet Inc. and Amazon.com have poured tens of billions of dollars into AI businesses. While these investments and partnerships are a\n\nlifeline for the startups, regulators have expressed concern that they threaten to concentrate access to the most innovative large language models among the tech companies that already dominate other platforms.\n\nTech giants are also striking non-financial agreements. These include Apple's partnership with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to the iPhone, and Microsoft's decision earlier this year to bring on Inflection AI's Mustafa Suleyman and most of his staff from the OpenAI rival.\n\nMicrosoft took on the non-voting observer role on OpenAI's board last year, weeks after the startup's directors had fired Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman in a dramatic coup over the direction of the company.\n\nAltman was quickly reinstated following a backlash from employees and the board was remade.\n\n\"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement to Bloomberg News,\n\nwithout commenting directly on Apple or Microsoft's decisions.\n\nOpenAI said that moving forward, the company will host regular stakeholder meetings with partners and investors, including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, \"to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nOpenAI began in 2015 as a nonprofit research organization, but later shifted its structure to include a for-profit startup that has solicited investments and struck commercial partnerships.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240710-microsoft-drops-openai-board-seat-as-scrunity-increases", "title": "Microsoft drops OpenAI board seat as scrunity increases", "body": "Brussels (Belgium) (AFP) - Microsoft has ditched plans to take up a non-voting position on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as regulators step up scrutiny of deals involving AI companies.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence the tech giant has over its smaller partner.\n\nIts early investment in OpenAI has made Microsoft a market leader in AI.\n\nWhen ChatGPT hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution as the chatbot dazzled users with its ability to churn out eloquent text in seconds.\n\nBut regulators began examining the partnership after a failed boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman -- whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nAfter the turmoil in OpenAI, Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", according to a letter sent from the company to OpenAI on Tuesday.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter stated.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe EU last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBrussels is however now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses\" could harm competition.\n\nMicrosoft is also under examination over its ties to OpenAI by British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\n\"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny,\" said Alex Haffner, a competition lawyer, at Fladgate law firm.\n\nMore scrutiny\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nApple had been due to get a seat after partnering with OpenAI for a suite of new AI features on its popular devices -- rolling out soon in markets outside the EU.\n\nThe bloc's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nWith regulators focused on \"the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers\", lawyer Haffner said there was a \"need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward\".\n\nAnother phenomenon in the AI market in the EU's crosshairs is so-called \"acqui-hires\" -- when a company acquires another firm mainly to grab its key talent -- with Brussels racing to understand if it distorts competition.\n\nMicrosoft earlier this year announced a deal to hire senior figures from OpenAI rival Inflection, including its boss, to head up a newly created consumer AI unit.\n\nBut unlike a merger, Inflection still operates as an independent company and such a move by Microsoft means it avoids a traditional merger probe.\n\nRegulators have the right to block mergers if there are fears of damage to competition.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [], "title": "World News | Microsoft Quits OpenAI Board Seat as Antitrust Scrutiny of Artificial Intelligence Pacts Intensifies | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, Jul 10 (AP) Microsoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being roiled by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a Tuesday letter, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately,\" from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\nAlso Read | Baba Vanga Predictions for 2025: 'End of the World' Will Start Next Year, Blind Mystic Aka Balkan Nostradamus' Timeline for Doomsday Goes Viral.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise departure comes amid intensifying scrutiny from antitrust regulators of the powerful AI partnership.\n\nAlso Read | PM Narendra Modi, Austrian Chancellor Karl Nehammer Hold Delegation-Level Talks in Vienna (Watch Video).\n\nMicrosoft has reportedly invested USD 13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's antitrust rules, while the US Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the pact.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind the ouster were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter. \"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nIt's not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was {"uri": "2024-07-417551445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:17:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:17:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/microsoft-apple-give-openai-board-seats", "title": "Microsoft, Apple Give Up OpenAI Board Seats", "body": "(RTTNews) - Tech majors Microsoft Corp. and Apple Inc. are dropping out of their respective seats on the Board of Directors of AI startup OpenAI, the developer of generative chatbot ChatGPT, amid the increasing regulatory scrutiny in Europe and the U.S. over generative AI, as per reports.\n\nMicrosoft, OpenAI's largest investor, has quit as an observer on OpenAI's nonprofit board, a non-voting seat, which it took in November last year. Microsoft's Deputy General Counsel Keith Dolliver, in a letter to OpenAI, said the seat was no longer needed as the company had witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board.\n\nFurther, Apple, which was planning to join the Board following its recent AI development deal, is said to be no longer taking the Board seat. At the Worldwide Developers Conference in June, Apple announced its partnership with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT into iOS 18. As part of the collaboration, Phil Schiller, the former marketing head and chief of the App Store at Apple, was selected to have an observer role on OpenAI's board, and was expected to join later this year .\n\nConfirming that Microsoft has given up its seat, OpenAI spokesperson Steve Sharpe reportedly said, \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership. Under the leadership of CFO Sarah Friar, we are establishing a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners - such as Microsoft and Apple - and investors - such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\"\n\nThe new approach by OpenAI is said to involve regular stakeholder meetings with Microsoft and Apple to share progress on its mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\n\nMicrosoft took the non-voting board seat at OpenAI during the troubling period of the startup last year, when its co-founder Sam Altman was ousted from the Board and as CEO after alleging that he was not consistently candid in his communications. Altman rejoined as CEO few days later, and also to the board after an independent Special Committee investigation found that his conduct did not mandate removal.\n\nThe news comes as the European Commission recently said Microsoft could face an antitrust investigation as the regulator was looking into some of the deals between large digital market players and generative AI developers and providers to find the impact of these partnerships on market dynamics. The Commission in January said it was checking whether Microsoft's investment in OpenAI might be reviewable under the EU Merger Regulation.\n\nThe views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.", "source": {"uri": "nasdaq.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NASDAQ Stock Market"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Similarly, Microsoft put an observer in place following 2023's chaotic ousting and then re-hiring of OpenAI CEO Sam Altman.\n\nAccording to multiple sources including the Financial Times, however, Microsoft has now withdrawn its observer. A source said to have direct knowledge of the matter, says that Apple will no longer take an observer board position.\n\nThe move by both Apple and Microsoft is believed to be related to scrutiny by global regulators. In particular, authorities in both the US and the European Union are reportedly examining OpenAI's partnership with Microsoft.\n\nApple has not confirmed that it will no longer take a seat on the board, nor commented on the report. {"uri": "2024-07-417076349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:30:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:30:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3011854-microsoft-and-apple-withdraw-observer-roles-on-openai-board-amid-regulatory-scrutiny", "title": "Microsoft and Apple Withdraw Observer Roles on OpenAI Board Amid Regulatory Scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft and Apple have relinquished their observer seats on OpenAI's board due to increased regulatory scrutiny. Microsoft had invested $13 billion in OpenAI's generative AI technology, ChatGPT. OpenAI announced a new strategy to engage partners. Analysts speculate various reasons for this decision, including strategic considerations and internal dynamics.\n\nIn a significant shift within the tech industry, both Microsoft and Apple have relinquished their observer seats on the board of OpenAI, as reported by UK-based 'The Financial Times'. This move coincides with growing regulatory scrutiny over the involvement of major tech firms in AI startups. Microsoft, which had heavily invested in OpenAI, including a notable USD 13 billion investment in its AI technology ChatGPT, has announced its immediate withdrawal from its observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nThe decision was communicated through a letter to OpenAI, citing the company's satisfaction with the progress made by the newly formed board. Similarly, Apple, which was expected to take up an observer role as part of a deal to integrate ChatGPT into its devices, has decided against doing so.\n\nWhile Apple declined to comment, sources suggest it will not be taking an observer position on OpenAI's board. In light of these changes, OpenAI has introduced a revised strategy for engaging with strategic partners and investors.\n\nAccording to the Financial Times report, OpenAI plans to hold regular meetings with partners such as Microsoft and Apple, alongside investors like Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures. This new approach aims to encourage a more inclusive and collaborative governance structure, stated an OpenAI spokesperson.\n\nRecently, Phil Schiller, former Apple marketing chief, was added as an observer on OpenAI's board just days before these withdrawals. However, Schiller will no longer be observing OpenAI's operations, underscoring the fluid dynamics within the organization.\n\nAnalysts speculate that Microsoft's and Apple's decisions to withdraw from their observer roles could be driven by strategic considerations or internal dynamics within OpenAI. {"uri": "8218772483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:17:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:17:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:16:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/news/199535", "title": "Microsoft drops OpenAI board seat as scrunity increases | News", "body": "BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 10, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Microsoft has ditched plans to take up a non-voting position on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as regulators step up scrutiny of deals involving AI companies.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence the tech giant has over its smaller partner.\n\nIts early investment in OpenAI has made Microsoft a market leader in AI.\n\nWhen ChatGPT hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution as the chatbot dazzled users with its ability to churn out eloquent text in seconds.\n\nBut regulators began examining the partnership after a failed boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman -- whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nAfter the turmoil in OpenAI, Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", according to a letter sent from the company to OpenAI on Tuesday.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter stated.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe EU last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBrussels is however now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses\" could harm competition.\n\nMicrosoft is also under examination over its ties to OpenAI by British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\n\"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny,\" said Alex Haffner, a competition lawyer, at Fladgate law firm.\n\n- More scrutiny -\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nApple had been due to get a seat after partnering with OpenAI for a suite of new AI features on its popular devices -- rolling out soon in markets outside the EU.\n\nThe bloc's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nWith regulators focused on \"the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers\", lawyer Haffner said there was a \"need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward\".\n\nAnother phenomenon in the AI market in the EU's crosshairs is so-called \"acqui-hires\" -- when a company acquires another firm mainly to grab its key talent -- with Brussels racing to understand if it distorts competition.\n\nMicrosoft earlier this year announced a deal to hire senior figures from OpenAI rival Inflection, including its boss, to head up a newly created consumer AI unit.\n\nBut unlike a merger, Inflection still operates as an independent company and such a move by Microsoft means it avoids a traditional merger probe.\n\nRegulators have the right to block mergers if there are fears of damage to competition.", "source": {"uri": "bssnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS)"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT", {"uri": "8218381372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:19:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:19:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:18:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://techmonitor.ai/technology/ai-and-automation/microsoft-seat-openai", "title": "Microsoft abandons observer seat on OpenAI board", "body": "The decision comes as Microsoft faces increasing regulatory scrutiny into its relationship with OpenAI in the US and UK\n\nMicrosoft has announced its abandonment of an observer seat on OpenAI's board. Originally granted last year by OpenAI in the wake of the abrupt firing and re-hiring of its founder and chief executive, Sam Altman, the big tech firm said in a letter to OpenAI that it no longer needed to keep the seat as governance at the startup had substantially improved since then.\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence,\" wrote Microsoft's deputy chief counsel Keith Dolliver. However, eight months on after the attempted coup against Altman at OpenAI, \"we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\" The seat is now vacant, with the Financial Times reporting that Apple - after announcing its own partnership with OpenAI last month - refusing to assume Microsoft's old position.\n\nThe gift of an observer board seat to Microsoft was, in part, a testament to the close relationship between OpenAI's chief executive Sam Altman and the Redmond-based firm's chief, Satya Nadella, with the latter going as far as to offer Altman a role at Microsoft during his brief hiatus from his startup. The partnership, which has seen Microsoft invest billions into OpenAI, has resulted in several market-leading AI innovations such as the former's Copilot service.\n\nSince then, however, multiple regulators have become increasingly critical about how that partnership may serve to inhibit competition within the overall marketplace for generative AI products. In June, the US Federal Trade Commission launched a probe into whether Microsoft and OpenAI's relationship broke antitrust laws. In December 2023, meanwhile, the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) mounted its own inquiry. Five months later, the watchdog's chief executive Sarah Cardell said that both Microsoft and Nvidia were two of six large firms that dominated the AI value chain through an \"interconnected web\" of 90 investments and partnerships.\n\nThese companies, argued Cardell, \"already hold positions of market power in many of today's most important digital markets [and] could profoundly shape these new markets to the detriment of fair, open and effective competition, ultimately harming businesses and consumers.\" The CMA's probe into Microsoft and OpenAI is ongoing, with some speculating that a Phase I investigation is likely to commence later this year.\n\nThis is not the first time Microsoft has seemingly attempted to stave off regulators' ire over its partnership with OpenAI. In December, after Microsoft announced its investment of $13bn into the firm, it did so as part of a deal that would see it receive limited profits from an OpenAI subsidiary. Redmond stressed, however, that it did not \"own any portion of OpenAI\" as part of this arrangement.\n\nThough Microsoft has decided to give up its observer seat on its board, OpenAI stressed that its relationship with the big tech firm would remain close. A spokesperson told the FT that OpenAI would instead consult with Microsoft and other major investors through regular meetings, as part of a \"new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners.\"", "source": {"uri": "techmonitor.ai", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tech Monitor"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8218575288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:15:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:15:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:14:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/07/10/microsoft-quits-openai-board-as-competition-scrutiny-of-ai-partnership-increases/", "title": "Microsoft quits OpenAI board as competition scrutiny of AI partnership increases", "body": "It said its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being rocked by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nMicrosoft has relinquished its seat on the board of OpenAI, saying its participation is no longer needed because the ChatGPT maker has improved its governance since being rocked by boardroom chaos last year.\n\nIn a letter on Tuesday, Microsoft confirmed it was resigning, \"effective immediately\", from its role as an observer on the artificial intelligence company's board.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nThe surprise move comes amid intensifying scrutiny from competition regulators of the powerful AI partnership. Microsoft has reportedly invested 13 billion US dollars (\u00a310.2 billion) in OpenAI.\n\nEuropean Union regulators said last month that they would take a fresh look at the partnership under the 27-nation bloc's competition rules, while the US Federal Trade Commission and Britain's competition watchdog have also been examining the deal.\n\nMicrosoft took the board seat following a power struggle in which OpenAI chief executive Sam Altman was fired, then quickly reinstated, while the board members behind his removal were pushed out.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly-formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft said in its letter.\n\n\"Given all of this, we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith Microsoft's departure, OpenAI will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement.\n\nAlex Haffner, a competition partner at UK law firm Fladgate, said it is not hard to conclude that Microsoft's decision to ditch the board seat was heavily influenced by rising scrutiny of big technology companies and their links with AI start-ups.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.\n\nOpenAI said it would take a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple and investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, with regular meetings to update stakeholders on progress and ensure stronger collaboration on safety and security.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218120057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:21:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://techcentral.co.za/microsoft-openai-board-observer-seat/247649/", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat - TechCentral", "body": "Microsoft has ditched its board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\nThe US tech giant took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the viral generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than US$10-billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the US over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the start-up for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated 9 July.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the UK and US antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI. -- Foo Yun Chee, with Krystal Hu and ExBulletin", "body": "Microsoft has announced that it will give up its observer status on the OpenAI board amid growing regulatory scrutiny of generative artificial intelligence in Europe and the United States.\n\nMicrosoft deputy general counsel Keith Dolliver wrote to OpenAI late Tuesday saying the role has provided insight into the board's activities without compromising its independence.\n\nBut the letter, seen by CNBC, added that the seat is no longer necessary because Microsoft has \"seen significant progress from its newly created board.\" CNBC has reached out to Microsoft and OpenAI for comment.\n\nThe European Commission had previously said Microsoft could face an antitrust investigation as a result of its investigation into the markets for virtual worlds and generative artificial intelligence.\n\nThe European Commission said in January that it was \"investigating several agreements concluded between large digital market players and generative AI developers and providers,\" specifically naming Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI as a target of its investigation.\n\nThe EU later concluded that the observer role did not alter OpenAI's independence, but EU regulators are seeking further independent opinions on the deal, and the UK Competition and Markets Authority remains concerned.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting seat on OpenAI's board of directors in November to allay some of the doubts about its interest in the startup, following a tumultuous period in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired and then quickly rehired.\n\nIn a memo to staff at the time, Altman said it was clear OpenAI \"made the right choice in partnering with Microsoft and is pleased that the company will join our new board as a non-voting observer.\"\n\nOpenAI has emerged as one of the hottest startups in the world since releasing its ChatGPT chatbot in late 2022. The technology allows users to enter simple text queries and get smart, creative answers that lead to deeper conversations.\n\nMicrosoft has poured billions of dollars into the startup, bringing its total investment to date to a reported $13 billion. {"uri": "8218895270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:33:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:33:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:32:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.theregister.com/2024/07/10/microsoft_to_withdraw_from_openais/", "title": "Microsoft withdraws from OpenAI's board", "body": "Redmond 'confident in the company's direction' says withdrawal letter\n\nMicrosoft is giving up its non-voting observer seat on OpenAI's board, citing progress in the company's direction - yet fear of regulatory scrutiny no doubt also played some part in the decision-making process.\n\nThe non-voting observer at Microsoft was parachuted onto OpenAI's board following the chaos of last year in which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was unceremoniously ejected then swiftly welcomed back. Rattled by the antics at OpenAI and the impact on its multibillion-dollar investment in the company, Microsoft took the seat to keep tabs on things.\n\nA European Commission review has since cleared Microsoft of trying to exert control over OpenAI. However, regulators are continuing to examine the company's behavior amid worries over the impact on competition of OpenAI and Microsoft's partnership.\n\nMicrosoft's relationship with OpenAI and the billions it has invested into the company has also come under scrutiny by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) as well as the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).\n\nWhile the European Commission opted not to pursue a review of the partnership under EU merger rules, the CMA's review is ongoing. Microsoft's decision to drop its non-voting observer seat means it has one less thing to defend regarding its relationship with OpenAI.\n\nIn the withdrawal letter seen by The Register, Keith Dolliver, Deputy General Counsel at Microsoft, wrote: \"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's transitional work without compromising its independence,\" he added.\n\nFollowing Microsoft's investment in OpenAI, the tech giant has gained an apparent early lead in the generative AI race and enjoyed increased earnings.\n\nAfter Apple's announcement that it would support OpenAI's ChatGPT in its products, the company was expected to take an observer seat on the board. However, according to reports, it has since elected not to.\n\nAlex Haffner, a competition partner at law firm Fladgate, told The Reg: \"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny of its (and other major tech players) influence over emerging AI players such as Open AI.\"\n\nHaffner observed that Microsoft had scored a \"win\" at the end of June with the European Commission dropping the merger control probe of Microsoft and OpenAI. However, he pointed out that regulators were still looking at the impact on AI competition of arrangements made by big tech.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" said Haffner. {"uri": "8218709687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:38:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:38:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://winbuzzer.com/2024/07/10/microsoft-steps-down-from-openai-board-position-xcxwbn/", "title": "Microsoft Steps Down from OpenAI Board, Apple Not Joining - WinBuzzer", "body": "The observer role one the OpenAI board was initially acquired by Microsoft following the November exit and then return of former OpenAI CEO Sam Altman. Microsoft was instrumental in facilitating Altman's return and the reconfiguration of the board.\n\nCurrently, the board features new members such as Bret Taylor as chairman and former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, alongside Adam D'Angelo, who remains from the previous board lineup. New board inductees include Instacart CEO Fidji Simo, ex-Sony Corp EVP Nicole Seligman, former Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation CEO Dr. Sue Desmond-Hellmann, and ex-NSA head Paul Nakasone.\n\nIn a communication to OpenAI, Microsoft declared its immediate withdrawal from the board observer role. The tech company thanked OpenAI's leadership for their cooperation during the transitional period. They highlighted that the observer role offered valuable oversight while maintaining board autonomy. With significant progress now achieved, Microsoft believes the role is no longer necessary.\n\nMicrosoft retains a 49% stake in the for-profit OpenAI, with investments totaling nearly $13 billion. The OpenAI-Microsoft partnership has attracted scrutiny from EU antitrust regulators, with Margrethe Vestager, EU's executive vice-president for competition policy, voicing concerns about large tech firms potentially gaining control over other companies through such investments.\n\nContrary to previous reports, Apple will not be taking a seat on OpenAI's board, The Financial Times has revealed. It was anticipated that Apple would assume an observer role on OpenAI's board as a part of the agreement to incorporate ChatGPT into its devices; however, this will not proceed, as stated by an individual with firsthand knowledge of the situation. Apple has chosen not to issue a statement on the matter.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson stated to The Verge that the company will host regular meetings with partners, including Microsoft and Apple, as well as investors like Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures. This initiative is part of \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners\" led by Sarah Friar, the newly appointed chief financial officer and former CEO of Nextdoor, who joined last month.\n\nPost Microsoft's departure from the observer position, OpenAI doesn't intend to appoint new observers to its board, as per sources familiar with the strategy. This decision could alleviate antitrust anxieties linked to Microsoft's deep involvement with OpenAI. OpenAI acknowledged Microsoft's faith in its governance and is set to formulate new strategies for engaging key strategic partners and investors, like Microsoft and Apple.\n\nUnder CFO Sarah Friar's supervision, OpenAI is crafting an approach to keep strategic partners and investors, including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, informed and engaged.\n\nMicrosoft's decision aligns with OpenAI's recent collaboration with Apple, which allows iPhone and Mac users to use Siri for ChatGPT queries. The AI firm continues to broaden its board, recently bringing former NSA official Paul Nakasone on board. Since the shake-ups at OpenAI last year, some key researchers, including Co-Founder Andrej Karpathy and Ilya Sutskever, have departed. "Microsoft gives up OpenAI board seat amid regulator scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft has ditched plans to take up an observer seat on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as antitrust regulators step up their scrutiny of the artificial intelligence market.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence it has over its smaller partner.\n\nRegulators began examining the partnership after an abortive boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nIt was after the turmoil in OpenAI that Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", the letter said.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft wrote to OpenAI in the letter sent on Tuesday.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nMore from this section Raebareli: MP Rahul Gandhi Offers Prayers at Hanuman to us!'\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's influential antitrust regulator, last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBut Microsoft was still under examination over the observer seat on the board from British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\nWhen {"uri": "8218301781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:27:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:27:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:27:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.siliconrepublic.com/business/microsoft-openai-board-observer-seat-apple-sam-altman", "title": "Microsoft gives up observer seat on OpenAI board", "body": "The decision comes as Microsoft faces antitrust scrutiny in the US owing to its close ties to OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft has decided to give up its observer seat on the board of OpenAI saying it has seen \"significant progress\" in the AI start-up and no longer feels it is necessary to hold one.\n\nThe non-voting observer seat was established when Microsoft played a key role in securing Sam Altman's return to OpenAI as CEO in November after he was briefly fired from the company.\n\nIn a letter sent to OpenAI and seen by multiple outlets, Microsoft said it has witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board over the past eight months and is \"confident\" in the company's direction.\n\n\"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change,\" the letter reads. \"Given [the progress] we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nAltman was unexpectedly fired by the company's board of directors in November after a \"deliberative review process\". The board claimed he had not been \"consistently candid in his communications\" and that it no longer had confidence in his ability to lead OpenAI.\n\nBut employees of the company, baffled by the lack of explanation given to them around Altman's dismissal, put pressure on the board to resign and reinstate the former CEO in what they believed to be his rightful position.\n\nMicrosoft CEO Satya Nadella, said at the time that the new board was a first essential step on a path to \"more stable, well-informed and effective governance\".\n\n\"Sam, Greg [Brockman]and I have talked and agreed they have a key role to play along with the OpenAI leadership team in ensuring OpenAI continues to thrive and build on its mission.\"\n\nMicrosoft's decision to give up the observer seat comes as the software giant faces antitrust regulatory scrutiny in the US owing to its close ties to OpenAI. Regulators want to probe whether deals existing between Microsoft, OpenAI and Nvidia give them an unfair advantage in the booming AI ecosystem.\n\nFollowing a partnership between Apple and the ChatGPT maker last month, a recent Bloomberg report revealed that OpenAI was planning to give Apple executive Phil Schiller an observer seat.\n\nHowever, following the departure of Microsoft, a source familiar with the matter told Axios that OpenAI no longer plans to have any observers on its board.\n\nFind out how emerging tech trends are transforming tomorrow with our new podcast, Future Human: The Series. ChatGPT.\n\nThe Cupertino colossus, which was given a seat as a major investor following the surprise firing of CEO Sam Altman last November, said in a letter that it was resigning its place on the board with immediate effect.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" the letter said.\n\nMicrosoft's deputy general counsel wrote the letter to OpenAI late on Tuesday, saying the seat was no longer needed as the company had \"witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nWith this move, OpenAI said it will no longer have observer seats on its board.\n\n\"We are {"uri": "8218787469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:25:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/microsoft-drops-openai-board-seat-as-scrunity-increases/article_b4a70164-d7e0-574d-a3d0-a2d54b92390e.html", "title": "Microsoft drops OpenAI board seat as scrunity increases", "body": "Microsoft has ditched plans to take up a non-voting position on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as regulators step up scrutiny of deals involving AI companies.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence the tech giant has over its smaller partner.\n\nIts early investment in OpenAI has made Microsoft a market leader in AI.\n\nWhen ChatGPT hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution as the chatbot dazzled users with its ability to churn out eloquent text in seconds.\n\nBut regulators began examining the partnership after a failed boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman -- whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nAfter the turmoil in OpenAI, Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", according to a letter sent from the company to OpenAI on Tuesday.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter stated.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe EU last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBrussels is however now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses\" could harm competition.\n\nMicrosoft is also under examination over its ties to OpenAI by British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\nMore from this section Scientists baffled by green frog that turned blue HEAT ALERT: Feels-like temps up to 99 degrees today; storms expect to end the workweek Top Biden Fundraisers Hit Pause as Donors Shy Away Following Debate Performance\n\n\"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny,\" said Alex Haffner, a competition lawyer, at Fladgate law firm.\n\n- More scrutiny -\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nApple had been due to get a seat after partnering with OpenAI for a suite of new AI features on its popular devices -- rolling out soon in markets outside the EU.\n\nThe bloc's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nWith regulators focused on \"the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers\", lawyer Haffner said there was a \"need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward\".\n\nAnother phenomenon in the AI market in the EU's crosshairs is so-called \"acqui-hires\" -- when a company acquires another firm mainly to grab its key talent -- with Brussels racing to understand if it distorts competition.\n\nMicrosoft earlier this year announced a deal to hire senior figures from OpenAI rival Inflection, including its boss, to head up a newly created consumer AI unit.\n\nBut unlike a merger, Inflection still operates as an independent company and such a move by Microsoft means it avoids a traditional merger probe.\n\nRegulators have the right to block mergers if there are fears of damage to competition.\n\nraz/ec/jxb", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218333618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:48:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/microsoft-and-apple-exit-observer-roles-on-openai-board-6073867", "title": "Microsoft And Apple Exit Observer Roles On OpenAI Board", "body": "The move comes amidst reports of increased regulatory scrutiny over the involvement of tech giants in AI startups.\n\nMicrosoft and Apple have exited the status of observer for OpenAI.\n\nIn a move reflecting shifting dynamics in the tech industry, both Microsoft and Apple have decided to relinquish their observer seats on the board of OpenAI, reported UK-based 'The Financial Times'. The move comes amidst reports of increased regulatory scrutiny over the involvement of tech giants in AI startups.\n\nMicrosoft, which had invested significantly in OpenAI, including a substantial USD 13 billion investment in its generative AI technology, ChatGPT, has announced its immediate withdrawal from its observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nThe decision was communicated via a letter to OpenAI, citing the company's satisfaction with the progress made by the newly formed board.\n\nSimilarly, Apple, which was expected to take up a similar observer role as part of an agreement to integrate ChatGPT into its devices, has opted not to do so.\n\nAlthough Apple declined to comment on the matter, sources familiar with the situation indicate that the tech giant will not be taking an observer position on OpenAI's board.\n\nIn response to these developments, OpenAI has announced a revised strategy for engaging with its strategic partners and investors.\n\nAccording to the FT report, the organization plans to hold regular meetings with partners like Microsoft and Apple, along with investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nThis shift, as explained by an OpenAI spokesperson, aims to foster a more inclusive and collaborative approach to governance and strategic decision-making.\n\nThe board of OpenAI recently saw the addition of Phil Schiller, Apple's former marketing chief, as an observer, which was reported just days before these withdrawals.\n\nHowever, Schiller will no longer be observing OpenAI's operations, highlighting the fluidity and perhaps underlying tensions within the organization's boardroom dynamics.\n\nAnalysts speculate that the decision by Microsoft and Apple to step back from their observer roles could be linked to strategic considerations or internal dynamics within OpenAI.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nWhile some suggest possible concerns over antitrust scrutiny or strategic disagreements, the exact motivations behind these decisions remain unclear.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", doesn't apply to Microsoft Azure's customers in the country.\n\nAzure operates in China via a joint venture and has made it clear in public statements that the AI models are available to its customers in the country, Seeking Alpha reported Monday (July 8), citing a paywalled article from The Information.\n\nOpenAI will reportedly block Chinese users from accessing its APIs beginning Tuesday (July 9), according to the report.\n\nNeither Microsoft nor OpenAI immediately replied to PYMNTS' request for comment.\n\nIt was reported on June 25 that OpenAI planned to take added measures to restrict China's access to its AI software by enforcing a policy the company already has to bar users in nations other than the territory the company supports.\n\nBloomberg noted in the report that OpenAI supports access to its services in dozens of countries, and that the company's guidelines say people accessing its products in countries not included on that list, like China, could have their accounts blocked or suspended.\n\nWhile the company's ChatGPT is not available in mainland China, companies have been able to build their own applications by accessing its API platform, Reuters reported June 25.\n\n\"We are taking additional steps to block API traffic from regions where we do not support access to OpenAI's services,\" an OpenAI spokesperson said in the report.\n\nIt was reported in January that the Biden administration proposed stringent regulations on major cloud service providers, including Microsoft, to compel these companies to identify and actively investigate foreign clients engaged in the development of AI applications on their platforms.\n\nThe Biden administration has also worked to limit China's access to advanced semiconductors.\n\nChina's rapid
