{"uri": "8218151967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:46:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:46:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:45:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/technology/tech-news/microsoft-leaves-openai-board-observer-seat-reasons-2611300", "title": "Microsoft Leaves OpenAI Board Observer Seat: Here's Why", "body": "OpenAI plans new stakeholder engagement strategies with Microsoft and Apple\n\nMicrosoft has decided to give up its observer seat on OpenAI's board due to regulatory scrutiny and significant improvements in the AI startup's governance as per a Reuters report. This move marks a shift in how major tech companies are navigating the complex landscape of AI development and regulation.\n\nIn November last year, Microsoft took a non-voting observer position on OpenAI's board after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman resumed leadership. This position allowed Microsoft to attend board meetings and access confidential information without voting rights. However, concerns from antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain, and the U.S. have prompted Microsoft to step back.\n\nMicrosoft cited substantial progress in OpenAI's governance and partnerships over the past eight months. A Microsoft letter to OpenAI dated July 9 stated, \"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this, we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nDespite Microsoft's explanation, antitrust regulators remain wary.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson announced a new strategy for stakeholder engagement. The company will host regular meetings with strategic partners like Microsoft and Apple, along with investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nInterestingly, Apple, which recently announced integrating OpenAI's ChatGPT into its devices, was expected to take up the observer role but has decided against it. The Financial Times reported this decision, citing a person with direct knowledge. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers. This competition aims to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators, addressing antitrust concerns. Additionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division.", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218561052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:07:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:07:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:06:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/business/company-news/2024/07/10/microsoft-apple-drop-openai-board-plans-as-scrutiny-grows/", "title": "Microsoft, Apple drop OpenAI board plans as scrutiny grows", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Microsoft Corp. and Apple Inc. dropped plans to take board roles at OpenAI in a surprise decision that underscores growing regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech's influence over artificial intelligence.\n\nMicrosoft, which invested US$13 billion in the ChatGPT creator, will withdraw from the board, the company said in a letter to OpenAI, which was seen by Bloomberg News. Apple was due to take up a similar role, but an OpenAI spokesperson said the startup will have no board observers after Microsoft's departure.\n\nRegulators in Europe and the U.S. had expressed concern about Microsoft's sway over OpenAI, applying pressure on one of the world's most valuable companies to show that it's keeping the relationship at arm's length. Microsoft has integrated OpenAI's services into its Windows and Copilot AI platforms and, like other big U.S. tech companies, is banking on the new technology to help drive growth.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft wrote in the memo. \"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nMicrosoft is facing broader scrutiny over its alleged dominance of artificial intelligence. The U.S. has started separate investigations into Microsoft's alleged dominance of the rapidly emerging field, and whether the company properly notified antitrust agencies about its deal with an OpenAI rival, Inflection AI, people familiar with the matter have said.\n\nEuropean regulators also said they were going to survey Microsoft's rivals about OpenAI's exclusive use of its technology, and the U.K.'s competition regulator is weighing a deeper investigation of the tie up.\n\nMicrosoft isn't being singled out. The U.K. is also looking into Amazon.com Inc.'s $4 billion collaboration with AI company Anthropic, expressing concern that large tech companies are using partnerships to \"shield themselves from competition.\" The U.S. is probing Nvidia Corp.'s dominance over AI chips.\n\nThe Financial Times reported Microsoft's exit earlier.\n\nThe biggest U.S. tech companies including Microsoft as well as Nvidia, Alphabet Inc. and Amazon.com have poured tens of billions of dollars into AI businesses. While these investments and partnerships are a lifeline for the startups, regulators have expressed concern that they threaten to concentrate access to the most innovative large language models among the tech companies that already dominate other platforms.\n\nTech giants are also striking non-financial agreements. These include Apple's partnership with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to the iPhone, and Microsoft's decision earlier this year to bring on Inflection AI's Mustafa Suleyman and most of his staff from the OpenAI rival.\n\nMicrosoft took on the non-voting observer role on OpenAI's board last year, weeks after the startup's directors had fired Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman in a dramatic coup over the direction of the company. Altman was quickly reinstated following a backlash from employees and the board was remade.\n\n\"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement to Bloomberg News, without commenting directly on Apple or Microsoft's decisions.\n\nOpenAI said that moving forward, the company will host regular stakeholder meetings with partners and investors, including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, \"to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nOpenAI began in 2015 as a nonprofit research organization, but later shifted its structure to include a for-profit startup that has solicited investments "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/microsoft-drops-openai-board-seat-as-scrunity-increases/article_b5f6184c-ec48-5af6-b4cb-08533d8a3f84.html", "title": "Microsoft drops OpenAI board seat as scrunity increases", "body": "Microsoft has ditched plans to take up a non-voting position on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as regulators step up scrutiny of deals involving AI companies.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence the tech giant has over its smaller partner.\n\nIts early investment in OpenAI has made Microsoft a market leader in AI.\n\nWhen ChatGPT hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution as the chatbot dazzled users with its ability to churn out eloquent text in seconds.\n\nBut regulators began examining the partnership after a failed boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman -- whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nAfter the turmoil in OpenAI, Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", according to a letter sent from the company to OpenAI on Tuesday.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" the letter stated.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe EU last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBrussels is however now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses\" could harm competition.\n\nMicrosoft is also under examination over its ties to OpenAI by British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\n\"It is hard not to conclude that Microsoft's decision has been heavily influenced by the ongoing competition/antitrust scrutiny,\" said Alex Haffner, a competition lawyer, at Fladgate law firm.\n\n- More scrutiny -\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nApple had been due to get a seat after partnering with OpenAI for a suite of new AI features on its popular devices -- rolling out soon in markets outside the EU.\n\nThe bloc's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nWith regulators focused on \"the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers\", lawyer Haffner said there was a \"need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward\".\n\nAnother phenomenon in the AI market in the EU's crosshairs is so-called \"acqui-hires\" -- when a company acquires another firm mainly to grab its key talent -- with Brussels racing to understand if it distorts competition.\n\nMicrosoft earlier this year announced a deal to hire senior figures from OpenAI rival Inflection, including its boss, to head up a newly created consumer AI unit.\n\nBut unlike a merger, Inflection still operates as an independent company and such a move by Microsoft means it avoids a traditional merger probe.\n\nRegulators have the right to block mergers if there are fears of damage to competition.\n\nraz/ec/jxb\n\nMore from this section\n\nDovenmuehle's Bernadette McDonnell named 2024 Mortgage Star {"uri": "8218402126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:31:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:31:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://spyglass.org/openai-board-apple-microsoft/", "title": "Nothing Boring About OpenAI's Board", "body": "Last week when the news broke that Apple would be getting a board observer role at OpenAI, I was surprised. Yes, the two companies had just announced a partnership to bake ChatGPT into Apple Intelligence, but this was still a highly unusual level of access as one of the largest companies in the world would be getting into arguably the most important AI startup. Normally such oversight is granted alongside ownership in an entity, but not only was Apple not investing in OpenAI, there was apparently no money changing hands in their deal. As I wrote:\n\nHaving been both a board member and a board observer at a number of companies over the years, you can't overstate how big of a deal this is. While it's true that observers don't get a formal vote on various governance issues, they're still in the room for every board meeting. Listening. Weighing in. It's obviously meant to be helpful (to both the company and the entity observing) and not nefarious, but it puts Apple in a position to know a lot of what's going on within OpenAI.\n\nYes, they can and will likely have recuse themselves for certain topics where there might be competitive overlap, but if OpenAI was overly concerned about this, they wouldn't have given Apple this position.\n\nWell, while OpenAI may not have had a problem with this, clearly someone did. As today comes news that Apple will not be getting that board observer role after all. From Tabby Kinder at The Financial Times:\n\nApple had also been expected to take an observer role on OpenAI's board as part of a deal to integrate ChatGPT into the iPhone maker's devices, but would not do so, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple declined to comment.\n\nOpenAI would instead host regular meetings with partners such as Microsoft and Apple and investors Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures -- part of \"a new approach to informing and engaging key strategic partners\" under Sarah Friar, the former Nextdoor boss who was hired as its first chief financial officer last month, an OpenAI spokesperson said.\n\nSo no one is refuting the reporting, first by Bloomberg and backed up by the FT, that Apple was in line to get this board role - going so far to note that longtime Apple executive Phil Schiller would be taking the position. Now that offer is being rescinded or declined. And while the attempt here is clearly to frame this all as \"nothing to see here\". Clearly there's something to see here! Because yes, Microsoft is also giving up their observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nThe Occam's razor guess would be that Microsoft wasn't thrilled with the notion of Apple getting equal footing in that board room. After all, it cost Microsoft roughly $15B to get that right, while it cost Apple $0. But beyond that, again, this is just a lot of access to grant a rival into Microsoft's largest and most important investment. I know that is an obvious guess because it's what I guessed last week:\n\nAnd my god, what must Microsoft think of this? I joked that it only cost them $15B or so to get what Apple just got for free. There had already been various reports of tensions between OpenAI and Microsoft around the Apple deal (and perhaps on the flip side, Microsoft's Inflection no-deal deal), but Microsoft must in part see this as letting the fox into the henhouse. The very expensive henhouse built with Microsoft's money!\n\nWell, now that gold-plated henhouse is secure again. All it took was mother hen leaving as well. A tall ask, perhaps, but Microsoft is obviously framing this as their decision to step down - per a memo obtained by Ina Fried:\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" Microsoft said.\n\n\"As you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board,\" Microsoft said in the letter. \"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change.\"\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" Microsoft added.\n\nI think it's quite likely that it was their decision - again, perhaps in exchange for ensure Apple didn't join those board meetings. But also, Microsoft having such a role always seemed problematic, simply from an optics perspective. Again, as I wrote:\n\nAnd Microsoft didn't even have observer rights until after the company nearly imploded and Satya Nadella stepped in to save and restore Sam Altman's job. To be fair, they probably didn't want to be in the board room beforehand simply because of the optics of that role alongside the massive investment (which alone has drawn the gaze of regulators). But once everything went to hell, they clearly felt the need to have more oversight - and understandably so!\n\nThe regulatory pressure is only increasing - especially as the \"hackqusition\" maneuver that Microsoft pioneered with Inflection (itself stemming from the near-hiring of Sam Altman and the rest of OpenAI back in November of 2023) spreads to other Big Tech companies. And Microsoft's investment in OpenAI itself remains under scrutiny. Sure, not having a formal board seat helps a bit, but again, they were still in that room. They were getting access to and input to all sorts of privileged information. That notion is why Microsoft called it a \"limited role\" but that's silly semantics. As someone who has been in such rooms many times, I can tell you, if you're in the room, you're in the room. The things you actually vote on as a director are usually stock grant approvals and the minutes from the last board meeting. It's true that Microsoft didn't have say over those elements, phew!\n\nBefore this site even existed, I found it odd that Microsoft would want any sort of formal role within OpenAI given the regulatory risk above. Again, clearly they felt the need to put \"an adult in the room\" after the near-implosion of the company, but that was after the new board was already being put in place. And yes, that board is now more built out than it was, impressively so, but there's no chance or reason for Microsoft to leave after just eight months (maybe two board meetings?) unless it was being used as a bargaining chip or to avoid regulatory scrutiny. And, I think in this case, both things are true.\n\nThis also alleviates some inevitable future tension in that board room if and when Apple - and Microsoft - continued to go down their own AI paths, working on projects that conflict with OpenAI. Back to my thoughts last week:\n\nYou can't help but get vibes of then-Google CEO Eric Schmidt on Apple's board. That ended in tension with the rise of Android. Apple is obviously already working on their own AI capabilities. And everyone assumes that they'll own more and more of that stack overtime, potentially pushing onto OpenAI's turf. The same is true of Microsoft, of course. But Microsoft owns 49% of OpenAI. Apple owns 0%.\n\nThe very real tension of Microsoft owning that 49% - sorry, having the right to 49% of the profits, you hear that, regulators? - remains and will undoubtedly also continue to increase. But that's going to be much, much more complicated to unwind. Perhaps OpenAI thought Apple could eventually be a new capital partner. Or perhaps Apple simply asked for more oversight alongside their partnership given the drama which constantly swirls around OpenAI. But again, that board element was also weird from that perspective because Apple has already stated that they were going to be bringing on other AI partners to be a part of Apple Intelligence eventually. OpenAI was simply the first.\n\nAnyway, henhouse secured. For now. The foxes are back outside. I'm sure this will appease regulators. Right? "Microsoft gives up OpenAI board seat amid regulator scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft has ditched plans to take up an observer seat on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, according to a letter seen by AFP on Wednesday, as antitrust regulators step up their scrutiny of the artificial intelligence market.\n\nMicrosoft's $13-billion tie-up with OpenAI has raised concerns on both sides of the Atlantic about just how much influence it has over its smaller partner.\n\nRegulators began examining the partnership after an abortive boardroom coup last year against OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, whom Microsoft supported and even briefly hired.\n\nIt was after the turmoil in OpenAI that Microsoft got a seat on the board as a non-voting observer that it is now giving up.\n\nMicrosoft's withdrawal is \"effective immediately\", the letter said.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft wrote to OpenAI in the letter sent on Tuesday.\n\n\"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nThe European Commission, the EU's influential antitrust regulator, last month concluded after a preliminary examination that Microsoft's investment did not mean it had taken control of OpenAI.\n\nBut Microsoft was still under examination over the observer seat on the board from British competition regulators, and faced a potential antitrust probe in the United States.\n\nWhen OpenAI's ChatGPT chatbot hit the scene in November 2022, it marked the popular arrival of the AI revolution.\n\nMedia reports said Apple had similarly given up the chance to sit on OpenAI's board, but the iPhone maker was not immediately available for comment.\n\nEU competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, has put big tech on alert over investments in the fast-growing AI market and insisted that the EU continues to keep an eye over the sector.\n\nBrussels is now seeking more information from Microsoft about the agreement with OpenAI, Vestager said on June 28, to understand whether \"certain exclusivity clauses could have a negative effect on competition\".\n\nraz/ec/rl\n\nMore from this section\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program\n\nDovenmuehle's Bernadette McDonnell named 2024 Mortgage Star Award Winner by Mortgage Women Apple was reportedly planning to join OpenAI's nonprofit board, but now the Financial Times reports that Apple will no longer join the board.\n\nOpenAI confirmed that Microsoft has given up its seat in a statement to The Verge, following reports from Axios and the Financial Times that Microsoft's deputy general counsel Keith Dolliver wrote a letter to OpenAI late on Tuesday.\n\n-snip-\n\nOpenAI's new approach towards Microsoft and Apple will involve hosting \"regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nThe changes to OpenAI's board come as antitrust concerns over Microsoft's deal with OpenAI have grown in recent months. It comes a week after Bloomberg spilled the beans on Apple's Phil Schiller prepping to join the OpenAI board, as part of an AI partnership between two companies.\n\nThe observer position that Microsoft assumed in November, following OpenAI CEO Sam Altman reclaiming his position, allowed the tech major led by Satya Nadella to attend OpenAI's board meetings without voting rights and access confidential information.\n\nMicrosoft's decision to ditch the observer seat is effective immediately. \"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" Microsoft said, according to Axios.\n\nMeanwhile, Apple, expected to assume a similar role, may not take on the observer position, FT reported, citing a \"person with direct knowledge of the matter\". Instead, OpenAI will hold regular meetings with partners such as Microsoft and Apple, as well as investors Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures. This forms part of a new strategy led by Sarah Friar, OpenAI's new CFO and former CEO of Nextdoor, to keep these key partners informed and engaged.\n\nIt's believed that antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain, and the U.S. are concerned about Microsoft's significant investment of over $10 billion in OpenAI and its observer seat, fearing it may wield too much influence over OpenAI. {"uri": "8218947568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:08:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:08:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:06:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/technology/3012539-microsoft-drops-board-observer-role-at-openai-amid-antitrust-scrutiny", "title": "Microsoft Drops Board Observer Role at OpenAI Amid Antitrust Scrutiny | Technology", "body": "Microsoft has relinquished its observer seat on OpenAI's board to alleviate antitrust concerns from U.S. and UK regulators regarding its control over the AI startup. Meanwhile, Apple has opted not to take an observer role on OpenAI's board. Both companies are addressing regulatory scrutiny and expanding their AI offerings.\n\nMicrosoft has decided to give up its board observer seat at OpenAI, aiming to alleviate concerns from U.S. and UK antitrust regulators over the extent of its influence on the AI startup amid the rising popularity of generative artificial intelligence.\n\nA source at the U.S. Federal Trade Commission indicated that this move might not resolve the agency's concerns, as they are reviewing antitrust issues related to transactions by Big Tech and top AI firms. At the same time, Apple, which recently announced plans to integrate OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT into its devices, has also decided against taking an observer role on OpenAI's board, according to the Financial Times.\n\nIn a letter to OpenAI, Microsoft mentioned its observer seat provided insights without compromising the board's independence and cited OpenAI's innovations and partnerships as reasons for relinquishing its position. Meanwhile, EU regulators have stated Microsoft does not control OpenAI under current merger rules, but British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to scrutinize Microsoft's influence.\n\nAn antitrust lawyer noted that by giving up the observer seat, Microsoft is making it more difficult for regulators to prove control over OpenAI. Users on the company's forums reported receiving emails from the company informing them of the policy.\n\nChina was conspicuously absent from the long list of supported countries, meaning that Chinese developers will not have access to the company's API for development. According to The Information, however, there is a significant workaround that runs straight through Microsoft Azure AI.\n\nDevelopers in China who want to take advantage of OpenAI's models can still do so if they sign up for an Azure account. Because of Microsoft and OpenAI's close relationship, this gives developers access to the AI firm's AI models through Microsoft's services.\n\nAccording to the outlet, the exception works because Azure China is a joint venture with Chinese company 21Vianet. Multiple customers confirmed to The Information that they had full access to OpenAI models within Azure.\n\nGiven the importance of the Chinese market, the revelation is good news for Microsoft, {"uri": "8218908229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:42:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:42:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:41:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.maginative.com/article/microsoft-departs-openais-board-2/", "title": "Microsoft Departs OpenAI's Board", "body": "Microsoft has given up its observer seat on OpenAI's board, just months after gaining the position during last year's leadership turmoil. The tech giant says it's now confident in OpenAI's direction and no longer needs the oversight role.\n\nFor context, last November, the AI community was shaken by the sudden firing of Sam Altman by OpenAI's board. The resulting chaos saw Microsoft play a pivotal behind-the-scenes role in facilitating Altman's return and restructuring the board. The turmoil led to a near-complete overhaul of OpenAI's board, retaining only one previous member, Adam D'Angelo, and adding new faces like Bret Taylor, Larry Summers, and recently, Paul Nakasone.\n\nIn a letter to OpenAI, Microsoft pointed to \"significant progress\" over the past eight months as the reason for its departure. \"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" the company stated. The letter also acknowledged the role of the observer seat in providing insights into the board's activities during a period of change.\n\nIn a statement, OpenAI responded to Microsoft's decision with gratitude and optimism. \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company.\"\n\nIn the wake of Microsoft's exit, OpenAI has also announced a shift in its approach to stakeholder engagement. Rather than observer board seats, the startup says it plans to now hold \"regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\" This change also affects Apple, which had been rumored to be in line for a similar position following a recent partnership to integrate ChatGPT with Siri.\n\nThe departure of Microsoft and the decision not to have any more observers on OpenAI's board come amid increasing scrutiny from antitrust regulators in the EU and the US. Both the European Commission and the Federal Trade Commission have been closely examining the partnerships between big tech companies and emerging AI players to prevent any undue influence that could stifle competition.\n\nMicrosoft's substantial investment in OpenAI, reportedly around $13 billion, has been instrumental in propelling the company to the forefront of the generative AI race. However, as regulatory bodies intensify their scrutiny, Microsoft appears to be taking a cautious approach to avoid drawing further regulatory attention.", "source": {"uri": "maginative.com", {"uri": "8218733317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:53:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:53:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:53:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://qz.com/microsoft-openai-apple-observer-board-seats-antitrust-1851584300", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board seat as regulatory scrutiny grows", "body": "Microsoft has reportedly dropped its seat as an observer on OpenAI's board of directors, less than eight months after it secured the post.\n\nThe Washington-based tech giant got its non-voting OpenAI board seat in November of 2023 after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was rehired following his short-lived forceful removal. Microsoft, which has invested more than $10 billion in the firm behind artificial intelligence chatbot ChatGPT, was \"blindsided\" by Altman's sudden firing last year.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Keith Dolliver, Microsoft's deputy general counsel, wrote in a letter to OpenAI Tuesday, according to The Financial Times and Axios.\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" Microsoft added in the letter as it announced its withdrawal of the seat \"effective immediately.\"\n\nApple, which recently got its own observer seat on OpenAI's board, has declined to accept the post, The Times reports. Phil Schiller, who leads Apple's App Store, was expected to fill the seat later this year. The two firms have announced a partnership to integrate ChatGPT 4-o into the latest iPhone operating system (iOS 18), iPadOS 18, and macOS Sequoia.\n\nOpenAI's new approach to keeping its partners, including the tech giants and investors like Thrive Capital, in the loop will be regular meetings, according to the Times.\n\nThe changes to OpenAI's board come as European and U.S. regulators have opened investigations into big tech companies over antitrust concerns.\n\nThe Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) have reached a deal to investigate Microsoft, Nvidia, and Open AI over potentially anti-competitive behavior in the AI space. The FTC is separately probing Microsoft over a deal to \"acqui-hire\" AI startup Inflection, as well as Amazon and Google's separate investments into Anthropic.\n\nThe United Kingdom's Competition and Markets Authority in December began gathering information to determine whether Microsoft and OpenAI's collaboration threatens competition. And the European Commission is weighing its own possible antitrust investigation into the tie-up.\n\nRepresentatives for Microsoft, OpenAI, and Apple did not immediately return requests for comment.", Britain's Competition and Markets Authority still has concerns.\n\nMicrosoft took a nonvoting board seat at OpenAI back in November in a bid to quell some of the questions about Microsoft's interest in the startup, following a turbulent period during which OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired, then promptly rehired.\n\nAltman said in a note to staff at the time that OpenAI \"clearly made the right choice to partner with Microsoft and I'm excited that our new board will include them as a non-voting observer.\"\n\nOpenAI emerged as one of the hottest startups globally after releasing its ChatGPT chatbot in late 2022. The tech allows users to input simple text queries and retrieve smart and creative answers that can lead to more in-depth conversations.\n\nMicrosoft has plowed billions of dollars into the startup, with its total investment to date reportedly swelling to $13 billion. {"uri": "8218545479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:57:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:57:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:57:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://fortune.com/2024/07/10/microsoft-apple-openai-board/", "title": "Microsoft and Apple abandon OpenAI board roles amid increasing regulatory scrutiny", "body": "Microsoft, which invested $13 billion in the ChatGPT creator, will withdraw from the board, the company said in a letter to OpenAI, which was seen by Bloomberg News. Apple was due to take up a similar role, but an OpenAI spokesperson said the startup will have no board observers after Microsoft's departure.\n\nRegulators in Europe and the US had expressed concern about Microsoft's sway over OpenAI, applying pressure on one of the world's most valuable companies to show that it's keeping the relationship at arm's length. Microsoft has integrated OpenAI's services into its Windows and Copilot AI platforms and, like other big US tech companies, is banking on the new technology to help drive growth.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction,\" Microsoft wrote in the memo. \"We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nMicrosoft is facing broader scrutiny over its alleged dominance of artificial intelligence. The US has started separate investigations into Microsoft's alleged dominance of the rapidly emerging field, and whether the company properly notified antitrust agencies about its deal with an OpenAI rival, Inflection AI, people familiar with the matter have said.\n\nEuropean regulators also said they were going to survey Microsoft's rivals about OpenAI's exclusive use of its technology, and the UK's competition regulator is weighing a deeper investigation of the tie up.\n\nMicrosoft isn't being singled out. The UK is also looking into Amazon.com Inc.'s $4 billion collaboration with AI company Anthropic, expressing concern that large tech companies are using partnerships to \"shield themselves from competition.\" The US is probing Nvidia Corp.'s dominance over AI chips.\n\nThe Financial Times reported Microsoft's exit earlier.\n\nThe biggest US tech companies including Microsoft as well as Nvidia, Alphabet Inc. and Amazon.com have poured tens of billions of dollars into AI businesses. While these investments and partnerships are a lifeline for the startups, regulators have expressed concern that they threaten to concentrate access to the most innovative large language models among the tech companies that already dominate other platforms.\n\nTech giants are also striking non-financial agreements. These include Apple's partnership with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to the iPhone, and Microsoft's decision earlier this year to bring on Inflection AI's Mustafa Suleyman and most of his staff from the OpenAI rival.\n\nMicrosoft took on the non-voting observer role on OpenAI's board last year, weeks after the startup's directors had fired Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman in a dramatic coup over the direction of the company. Altman was quickly reinstated following a backlash from employees and the board was remade.\n\n\"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" OpenAI said in a statement to Bloomberg News, without commenting directly on Apple or Microsoft's decisions.\n\nOpenAI said that moving forward, the company will host regular stakeholder meetings with partners and investors, including Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures, \"to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nOpenAI began in 2015 as a nonprofit research organization, but later shifted its structure to include a for-profit startup that has solicited investments {"uri": "2024-07-417279010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:26:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:26:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:03:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/sam-altman-openai-microsoft-board-departure-1923118", "title": "Microsoft leaves Sam Altman's OpenAI board", "body": "Microsoft, which has invested $13 billion into Sam Altman's most well-known company, said that its observer role was \"no longer necessary\" in a letter sent to OpenAI and seen by the Financial Times. Microsoft had accepted the non-voting board position in the wake of Altman's surprise removal and reinstatement as CEO of OpenAI last year.\n\nThe news comes after European and American antitrust authorities announced investigations into the partnership between the two tech companies. The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department both approved potential antitrust examinations due to the growth of artificial intelligence as a significant industry.\n\nMicrosoft's partnership with OpenAI, which was co-founded by Altman, Elon Musk and several other tech visionaries, was a significant part in the fledgling company's ability to grow and develop ChatGPT. Among other things, the investment enabled OpenAI quick access to high-level computing power and cloud storage.\n\nThe FT reported that in the letter, Microsoft Deputy General Counsel Keith Dolliver said: \"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence. We have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\nDolliver maintained that OpenAI remained one of Microsoft's \"most valued partners\" in the artificial intelligence space.\n\nIn response to the letter, a spokesperson for OpenAI told the FT: \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nMicrosoft gained the observational position on the board after Altman was removed as CEO in a coup in November last year, only to be reinstated less than a week later. At the time, the board said that they had lost confidence in Altman's leadership, due to a lack of communication.\n\nMicrosoft immediately hired Altman, along with OpenAI president Greg Brockman, to lead a new AI research lab. More than 700 OpenAI employees signed a letter threatening to quit and join the new Microsoft venture, pressuring the board to agree to Altman's return a few days later.\n\nIn the following days, Microsoft executive Dee Templeton was added to the OpenAI board, a seat which the company has retained until now.\n\nThe Financial Times reported that Apple, which recently announced a new partnership with OpenAI, would not be taking a similar observer role on the board despite previous expectations to do so.\n\nDo you have a story we should be covering? {"uri": "8218651147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:03:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:03:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:03:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.engadget.com/microsoft-and-apple-give-up-their-openai-board-seats-120022867.html", "title": "Microsoft and Apple give up their OpenAI board seats", "body": "Both companies are reportedly stepping back in the midst of EU antitrust scrutiny.\n\nMicrosoft has withdrawn from OpenAI's board of directors a couple of weeks after the European Commission revealed that it's taking another look at the terms of their partnership, according to the Financial Times. The company has reportedly sent OpenAI a letter, announcing that it was giving up its seat \"effective immediately.\" Microsoft took on an observer, non-voting role within OpenAI's board following an internal upheaval that led to the firing (and eventual reinstatement) of the latter's CEO, Sam Altman.\n\nAccording to previous reports, Apple was also supposed to get an observer seat at the board following its announcement that it will integrate ChatGPT into its devices. The Times says that will no longer be the case. Instead, OpenAI will take on a new approach and hold regular meetings with key partners, including the two Big Tech companies. In the letter, Microsoft reportedly told OpenAI that it's confident in the direction the company is taking, so its seat on the board is no longer necessary.\n\nThe company also wrote that its seat \"provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence,\" but the European Commission wants to take a closer look at their relationship before deciding if it agrees. \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership,\" an OpenAI spokesperson told The Times.\n\nMicrosoft initially invested $1 billion into OpenAI in 2019. Since then, the company has poured more money into the AI company until it has reached $13 billion in investments. The European Commission started investigating their partnership to figure out if it breaks the bloc's merger rules last year, but it ultimately concluded that Microsoft didn't gain control of OpenAI. It didn't drop the probe altogether, however -- Margrethe Vestager, the commission's executive vice-president for competition policy, revealed in June that European authorities asked Microsoft for additional information regarding their agreement \"to understand whether certain exclusivity clauses could have a negative effect on competitors.\"\n\nThe commission is looking into the Microsoft-OpenAI agreement as part of a bigger antitrust investigation. It also sent information requests to other big players in the industry that are also working on artificial intelligence technologies, including Meta, Google and TikTok. The commission intends to ensure fairness in consumer choices and to examine acqui-hires to \"make sure these practices don't slip through [its] merger control rules if they basically lead to a {"uri": "8218631908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:51:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:51:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:51:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/technology/article/2024/jul/10/microsoft-drops-observer-seat-on-openai-board-amid-regulator-scrutiny", "title": "Microsoft drops observer seat on OpenAI board amid regulator scrutiny", "body": "Startup's new approach means Apple will no longer be able to appoint executive to similar role\n\nMicrosoft has withdrawn its observer seat on the OpenAI board and Apple will no longer be able to appoint an executive to a similar role, amid regulatory scrutiny of big tech's relationship with artificial intelligence startups.\n\nMicrosoft, the largest financial backer of the ChatGPT developer, announced the move in a letter to the startup, as first reported by the Financial Times. It said the resignation of the observer role, which does not carry a vote in board decisions, was \"effective immediately\".\n\nMicrosoft said it had seen significant progress by OpenAI's new board, which was formed in the wake of the dramatic sacking and reinstatement of the chief executive, Sam Altman, last year. It said OpenAI was going in the right direction, including a commitment to safety and building a \"great culture\".\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" said Microsoft, which has invested $13bn (\u00a310.2bn) into OpenAI.\n\nHowever, it is understood that Microsoft believed the observer role was causing concern among competition regulators. In the UK, the Competition and Markets Authority is reviewing whether the partnership has resulted in \"an acquisition of control\", while in the US the Federal Trade Commission is also looking at the partnership.\n\nThe European Commission has decided not to conduct a formal merger review into Microsoft's investment in OpenAI but is scrutinising exclusivity clauses in the agreement between the companies.\n\nAn OpenAI spokesperson said that the San Francisco-based startup was establishing a new approach to \"informing and engaging key strategic partners\" such as Microsoft and Apple as well as other financial investors.\n\n\"Moving forward, we will host regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security. We look forward to continuing to receive feedback and advice from these key stakeholders,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nOpenAI will no longer have board observers under the new approach, which rules out Apple taking up such a role. It was reported this month that Apple was set to place the head of its app store, Phil Schiller, on the board as part of an agreement announced in June. Apple has been approached for comment.\n\nInvestments in AI startups are coming under scrutiny from regulators. As well as looking at Open AI and Microsoft, the FTC has said it is examining tie-ups between Anthropic, the company behind the Claude chatbot, and two tech powerhouses: Google and Amazon. In the UK, the CMA is also looking at Amazon and Anthropic as well as Microsoft's partnerships with Mistral and Inflection AI.\n\nAlex Haffner, a partner at the UK law firm Fladgate, said it was \"hard not to conclude\" that Microsoft's decision had been influenced by the regulatory environment.\n\n\"It is clear that regulators are very much focused on the complex web of inter-relationships that big tech has created with AI providers, hence the need for Microsoft and others to carefully consider how they structure these arrangements going forward,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": We no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" Microsoft wrote.\n\nMicrosoft, which invested $13bn in OpenAI, has been under watch by EU regulators for its use of the ChatGPT maker's technology. billion investment in its generative AI technology, ChatGPT, has announced its immediate withdrawal from its observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nThe decision was communicated via a letter to OpenAI, citing the company's satisfaction with the progress made by the newly formed board.\n\nSimilarly, Apple, which was expected to take up a similar observer role as part of an agreement to integrate ChatGPT into its devices, has opted not to do so.\n\nAlthough Apple declined to comment on the matter, sources familiar with the situation indicate that the tech giant will not be taking an observer position on OpenAI's board.\n\nIn response to these developments, OpenAI has announced a revised strategy for engaging with its strategic partners and investors.\n\nAccording to the FT report, the As confirmed by an OpenAI spokesperson to Bloomberg, Apple will also refrain from board participation.\n\nWhile Apple won't directly influence OpenAI's board, the companies' collaborative efforts, such as bringing ChatGPT to the iPhone, will continue.\n\nREAD MORE: Apple Joins OpenAI's Board: Phil Schiller Takes Observer Role in Historic Partnership\n\nOver the past few weeks, regulatory bodies in the US and Europe have raised concerns over Microsoft's potential dominance over OpenAI, prompting the tech giant to maintain a more distanced relationship. Recently, VCPost also reported that CIR will be considering legal action against OpenAI and Microsoft for using AI in their news content without consent.\n\nIn addition, the company has been facing antitrust scrutiny due to bundling Teams with other Microsoft Office software.\n\nHowever, Microsoft is not alone in facing scrutiny; other tech giants are also under the microscope. The UK's competition regulator is also investigating Amazon's $4 billion collaboration with AI company Anthropic, and the US is probing Nvidia's dominance in AI chips.\n\nDespite the withdrawal, Microsoft and OpenAI will continue their partnership, but due to the role of the board seat, they will not have regulatory oversight.\n\nOpenAI also plans to maintain regular stakeholder meetings with {"uri": "8218686042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:23:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:23:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:23:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.investopedia.com/microsoft-apple-step-back-from-openai-board-amid-antitrust-push-8675713", "title": "Microsoft, Apple Step Back From OpenAI Board Amid Antitrust Push", "body": "Microsoft (MSFT) has reportedly stepped back from its non-voting board seat on the board of ChatGPT maker OpenAI less than a year after joining it, while Apple (AAPL) has reportedly declined the opportunity to take a similar role as it integrates ChatGPT into new iPhones and operating systems.\n\nThe decisions, reported by The Financial Times and Bloomberg early Wednesday, come as regulators in the U.S. and abroad have stepped up efforts to rein in the influence of big tech companies in recent months.\n\nMicrosoft first took the board seat following a tumultuous period for the generative AI startup in November 2023, when the board fired and then rehired Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Sam Altman within days.\n\nIn a letter reportedly sent to OpenAI late Tuesday, Microsoft said it had seen \"significant progress\" over the last eight months, putting it in a position where its confidence in OpenAI's future makes it no longer necessary to retain its advisory board seat, the FT reported.\n\nApple, which announced a new partnership with OpenAI at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) last month, reportedly has passed on the chance to also have a non-voting board seat as its partnership with OpenAI develops. An OpenAI spokesperson told the FT that it plans to hold regular meetings with investors and partners like Apple and Microsoft to keep them informed.\n\nMicrosoft, Apple, and OpenAI did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nMicrosoft and Apple shares were both up about 0.4% by 8:15 a.m. ET Wednesday to $461.27 and $229.68, respectively.", "source": {"uri": The decision follows the rising popularity of generative AI and aims to address regulatory apprehensions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI. Despite Microsoft's $10 billion investment in OpenAI, the company emphasized continued collaboration while maintaining OpenAI's independence.\n\nIn a strategic move to address regulatory concerns, Microsoft has relinquished its observer seat on OpenAI's board. This decision comes as U.S. and UK antitrust regulators scrutinize Microsoft's influence over the fast-growing AI startup.\n\nMicrosoft's observer role, which provided non-voting access to confidential board discussions, was seen as a potential control mechanism by watchdogs despite the firm's significant investment in OpenAI. The position was initially taken up in November after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman resumed leadership.\n\nIn a letter dated July 9, Microsoft cited OpenAI's recent successes and growing customer base as reasons for stepping back, asserting confidence in the startup's direction. However, a report says that people in China can still access those models via a Microsoft Service.\n\n\"OpenAI's conversational Al models are available to Chinese businesses-if they sign up for Microsoft's Azure cloud service, which operates in China through a local joint venture,\" reports The Information, citing the company's public statements.\n\nMicrosoft operates as a joint venture with local company 21Vianet to offer Azure's OpenAI service in China. \"And three Azure China customers confirmed that they have access to OpenAI's models,\" the report added.\n\nWhat Microsoft has to say\n\nAn online publication PYMNTS cited a Microsoft spokesperson as saying that there has been no change to Microsoft's Azure OpenAI Service offerings in China. The spokesperson reportedly said that the company continues to provide access to eligible customers in the country, via models deployed in regions outside China. The spokesperson added that OpenAI is an independent company and makes its own decisions.\n\nLately, several reports suggested that any foreign company that wants to offer AI models in China will have to get them approved by the authorities and partner with a Chinese company. For example, Apple is reportedly looking to partner with a Chinese AI company to launch its Apple Intelligence features in China.\n\nThis is because ChatGPT is banned in the country, and the company must find a local Al chatbot that will work alongside Siri to handle requests for Al-generated content, a report by The Wall Street Journal said. Reportedly, Apple held talks with Baidu, Alibaba Group and Beijing-based startup Baichuan Al.\n\nWhat it means for Chinese Al companies\n\nFollowing the development, Chinese Al companies swiftly moved to attract those who use OpenAI's chatbot tools. {"uri": "8219205092", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:17:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:17:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:16:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.webpronews.com/microsoft-gives-up-its-openai-board-seat/", "title": "Microsoft Gives Up Its OpenAI Board Seat", "body": "Microsoft has opted to give up its seat on OpenAI's board, a position it has held since the AI firm's tumultuous boardroom coup last year.\n\nOpenAI's board of directors stunned the industry when it fired CEO Sam Altman in late 2023. The fallout was swift and severe, with Microsoft hiring Altman and co-founder Greg Brockman, as well as offering to hire any and all OpenAI engineers that wished to leave. Following intense pressure from the company's employees, as well as those outside the company, the board finally caved and brought Altman and Brockman back.\n\nIn the aftermath of the coup, the majority of the board resigned, and Microsoft was given a seat on the board to help improve its governance. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella made clear at the time that OpenAI's governance model had to change.\n\n\"At this point, I think it's very clear that something has to change around the governance,\" Nadella said in November 2023, adding that the company would have \"a good dialogue with their board on that.\"\n\nWith the OpenAI's boardroom drama largely stabilized, Microsoft is now giving up its board seat in an effort to stave off regulatory scrutiny. Regulators on both sides of the Atlantic have been taking a closer look at the AI industry, in particular the dominant role Big Tech companies are playing.\n\nGiven that Microsoft is one of OpenAI's largest donors, has a long-term contract with the firm, and had a seat on the board, the Redmond company evidently decided it would be prudent to relinquish its seat.\n\n\"We appreciate the support shown by OpenAI leadership and the OpenAI board as we made this decision,\" Microsoft said in a letter to OpenAI that was seen by Axios.\n\n\"As you know, we accepted the non-voting board observer role at a time when OpenAI was in the process of rebuilding its board,\" Microsoft continued. \"This position provided insights into the board's activities without compromising its independence, and we appreciated the opportunity to serve as an observer during this period of change.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction.\"\n\n\"Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" Microsoft added.", "source": {"uri": "webpronews.com", "dataType": The job allows someone to attend board meetings without being able to vote or exercise other director powers. {"uri": "8219044992", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:11:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:11:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:11:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cryptotimes.io/2024/07/10/microsoft-apple-step-down-from-openai-board-as-scrutiny-grows/", "title": "Microsoft, Apple Step Down from OpenAI Board As Scrutiny Grows", "body": "Microsoft Corp. and Apple Inc. decided to withdraw from their planned board roles at OpenAI amid increasing regulatory scrutiny of Big Tech's influence over artificial intelligence.\n\nMicrosoft, a $13 billion investor in OpenAI, resigned from its non-voting observer position, citing trust in the organization's direction and recent advancements. Apple had planned to play a similar role, but with Microsoft's exit, it will also choose not to be a board observer.\n\nRegulators from the US and Europe have voiced worries regarding the power big tech corporations like Microsoft have over the advancement of AI. As with other major IT firms in the US, Microsoft has included OpenAI's services into its Windows and Copilot AI platforms and is counting on the new technology to spur growth.\n\nIn an internal memo, Microsoft shares its confidence in OpenAI's path and has observed notable development from the company's new board, so they no longer need to play the spectator role.\n\nMicrosoft is coming under increased scrutiny because of its claimed superiority in artificial intelligence. The United States is separately investigating whether Microsoft properly notified antitrust officials about its deal with Inflection AI and why the company is so dominant in AI.\n\nAdditionally, European regulators announced that they will question Microsoft's competitors regarding OpenAI's exclusive use of its technology, and the competition authority in the United Kingdom is considering a more thorough examination of the partnership.\n\nThe regulatory pressure is a reflection of wider worries about the concentration of AI innovation within a small number of very large tech firms. Concerns over Amazon's $4 billion partnership with AI startup Anthropic and Nvidia's hegemony in the AI chip industry are also being voiced in the UK.\n\nMajor U.S. tech companies like Microsoft, Nvidia, Alphabet, and Amazon have invested heavily in AI, raising regulatory concerns about concentrated access to advanced technologies. Non-financial agreements include Apple's partnership with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to the iPhone and Microsoft's hiring of Inflection AI's Mustafa Suleyman.\n\nOpenAI thanked Microsoft for its confidence in the board and company direction. The organization plans regular stakeholder meetings with partners like Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures to enhance collaboration on safety and security.", "source": {"uri": "cryptotimes.io", compromising its independence.\n\nBut the letter added that the seat was no longer needed Microsoft had \"witnessed significant progress from the newly formed board,\" according to the Financial Times.\n\nCNBC has reached out to Microsoft and OpenAI for comment.\n\nThe European Commission previously said Microsoft could face an antitrust investigation, as it looked at the markets for virtual worlds and generative artificial intelligence.\n\nThe Commission, which is the executive arm of the EU, said in January that it is \"looking into some of the agreements that have been concluded \"clearly made the right choice to partner with Microsoft and I'm excited that our new board will include them as a non-voting observer.\"\n\nOpenAI emerged as one of the hottest startups globally {"uri": "8219155298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:36:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:36:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/microsoft-and-apple-back-away-from-openai-board-amid-regulator-scrutiny", "title": "Microsoft and Apple back away from OpenAI board amid FTC scrutiny", "body": "With potential antitrust concerns hovering around OpenAI, the two tech companies are cutting bait before the FTC and CMA turn attention towards them.\n\nAs OpenAI is getting more focus from regulators like the FTC, Microsoft and Apple are both distancing themselves from the ChatGPT maker.\n\nPer Ars Technica, both tech giants have elected not to join OpenAI's board after previously signing their allegiance. The former accepted an observer role in November 2023 as Sam Altman was ousted (and returned) from OpenAI.\n\nNotably, this comes almost a full year after the FTC launched its investigation into the generative AI company. At the time, it believed ChatGPT potentially violated consumer protection laws and harmed consumers.\n\nThe exit of both companies means OpenAI no longer has any observers on the board. On Microsoft and Apple's side, this absolves them of any potential (and further) antitrust attention from regulators.\n\nIn a letter obtained by Axios, Microsoft said this move was effective immediately. Given the \"significant progress\" of OpenAI's new board, the Xbox maker \"no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary.\"\n\nAs for Apple, it announced a partnership with OpenAI in June, promising iPhone and Mac users could use Siri to query the latter's ChatGPT product. In exchange, Apple executive Phil Schiller was reportedly promised an observer role similar to Microsoft.\n\nWhile the two companies have left their observer roles, an OpenAI representative told The Verge affirmed it would still work with Microsoft and Apple. OpenAI plans to hold \"regular stakeholder meetings to share progress on our mission and ensure stronger collaboration across safety and security.\"\n\nPreviously, Microsoft talked about its plans to integrate genAI into its ecosystem. Along with design tools powered by the technology for its game studios, the company Copilot AI program will be integrated into its Xbox and PC games, like an always-on strategy guide.\n\nGenerative AI has faced plenty of criticism from creative workers in fields like writing and art over the past year. But attention has also been given to its environmental damage and how much energy it takes out of data centers.\n\nBut as the FTC and CMA begin cracking down on the technology, companies like Microsoft, Apple, and Google have yet to fully back off from it. Search features and chatbots powered by genAI are still active at time writing, and it may be that they remain until genuine government regulation dictate actual rules surrounding it.", "source": {"uri": "8219052176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:17:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:17:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:16:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://thecyberexpress.com/microsoft-exits-openai-board/", "title": "Microsoft Exits OpenAI Board Amid Regulatory Pressure", "body": "The move comes just days after reports suggested Apple might take an observer role on the board, but now the Cupertino giant has also opted out\n\nIn a move likely fueled by intensifying antitrust scrutiny, Microsoft is exiting OpenAI and stepping down from its non-voting observer seat of the AI company's board of directors. This comes just days after reports suggested Apple might take a similar observer role, but now the Cupertino giant has also opted out.\n\nMicrosoft's exit, communicated via a letter on Tuesday, cited \"significant progress\" made by OpenAI's newly formed board, according to Axios. This explanation rings somewhat hollow, considering Microsoft's role was established just last November following a period of upheaval at OpenAI that saw the ousting and reinstatement of CEO Sam Altman.\n\nOpenAI announced a new safety and security committee in May end as it began training a new AI model intended to replace the GPT-4 chatbot. A month later, OpenAI pushed out the rollout of its highly anticipated \"Voice Mode\" feature for ChatGPT to July, citing safety concerns. The company said it needed more time to ensure the model could \"detect and refuse certain content.\"\n\nThe timing of these decisions coincides neatly with growing regulatory pressure on Big Tech's influence in the burgeoning field of artificial intelligence. Both the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the European Commission (EC) have expressed concerns that tech giants' investments in AI startups like OpenAI could stifle competition and create monopolies in key technological areas.\n\nIn June, the FTC launched an investigation into Big Tech investments in generative AI startups, including Microsoft, Amazon, and Google. The EC, meanwhile, explored the possibility of an antitrust probe into the Microsoft-OpenAI partnership after deciding against a merger control investigation.\n\nWhile both Microsoft and OpenAI maintain the company's independence despite the multi-billion dollar investment, the optics surrounding the close relationship are not lost on regulators. Microsoft's access to cutting-edge AI models through this partnership gives them a significant advantage, potentially hindering the growth of smaller competitors.\n\nOpenAI seems to be taking a new approach to partner engagement. Moving forward, they plan to host regular meetings with key partners like Microsoft and Apple, alongside investors, to foster communication and collaboration. This strategy aims to maintain strong relationships without raising red flags for regulators.\n\nThe future trajectory of Big Tech's involvement in AI development remains to be seen. The recent retreat from board positions suggests a potential shift as companies navigate the increasingly complex regulatory landscape as they strive to maintain a competitive edge in the race for AI {"uri": "8218205850", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:23:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:23:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:23:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/business/microsoft-and-apple-exit-observer-roles-on-openai-board20240710125042/", "title": "Microsoft and Apple exit observer roles on OpenAI board", "body": "New Delhi [India], July 10 (ANI): In a move reflecting shifting dynamics in the tech industry, both Microsoft and Apple have decided to relinquish their observer seats on the board of OpenAI, reported UK-based 'The Financial Times'. The move comes amidst reports of increased regulatory scrutiny over the involvement of tech giants in AI startups.\n\nMicrosoft, which had invested significantly in OpenAI, including a substantial USD 13 billion investment in its generative AI technology, ChatGPT, has announced its immediate withdrawal from its observer role on OpenAI's board.\n\nThe decision was communicated via a letter to OpenAI, citing the company's satisfaction with the progress made by the newly formed board.\n\nSimilarly, Apple, which was expected to take up a similar observer role as part of an agreement to integrate ChatGPT into its devices, has opted not to do so.\n\nAlthough Apple declined to comment on the matter, sources familiar with the situation indicate that the tech giant will not be taking an observer position on OpenAI's board.\n\nIn response to these developments, OpenAI has announced a revised strategy for engaging with its strategic partners and investors.\n\nAccording to the FT report, the organization plans to hold regular meetings with partners like Microsoft and Apple, along with investors such as Thrive Capital and Khosla Ventures.\n\nThis shift, as explained by an OpenAI spokesperson, aims to foster a more inclusive and collaborative approach to governance and strategic decision-making.\n\nThe board of OpenAI recently saw the addition of Phil Schiller, Apple's former marketing chief, as an observer, which was reported just days before these withdrawals.\n\nHowever, Schiller will no longer be observing OpenAI's operations, highlighting the fluidity and perhaps underlying tensions within the organization's boardroom dynamics.\n\nAnalysts speculate that the decision by Microsoft and Apple to step back from their observer roles could be linked to strategic considerations or internal dynamics within OpenAI.\n\nWhile some suggest possible concerns over antitrust scrutiny or strategic disagreements, the exact motivations behind these decisions remain unclear. {"uri": "2024-07-416970438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:32:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:32:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:24:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/technology/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-seat-amid-regulatory-scrutiny-2024-07-10/", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny", "body": "BRUSSELS, July 10 (Reuters) - Microsoft (MSFT.O)New Tab, opens new tab has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\niPhone maker Apple (AAPL.O)New Tab, opens new tab had also been expected to take an observer role on OpenAI's board but would notNew Tab, opens new tab do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\nReporting by Foo Yun Chee; Additional reporting by Krystal Hu and Jeffrey Dastin in San Francisco and Nilutpal Timsina in Bangalore; Editing by Jamie Freed and Miral Fahmy\n\nFoo Yun Chee\n\nThomson Reuters\n\nAn agenda-setting and market-moving journalist, Foo Yun Chee is a 20-year veteran at Reuters. {"uri": "8218253898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:57:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:57:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:56:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/tech-news/microsoft-gives-up-position-on-chatgpt-maker-openais-board/articleshow/111628060.cms", "title": "Microsoft gives up position on ChatGPT maker OpenAI's board - Times of India", "body": "Microsoft has reportedly given up its seat on OpenAI's board as global antitrust regulators step up scrutiny of Big Tech's influence in artificial intelligence. According to a report in Reuters, Microsoft Corp has relinquished the chance to be observers on OpenAI's board. The report quotes a person familiar with the matter, asking not to be identified discussing a private move.\n\nMicrosoft is said to have sent a letter regarding the same to the ChatGPT maker OpenAI.The letter announces the company's decision to withdraw from the AI startup's board. Microsoft has invested $13 billion in OpenAI.\n\nWhy Microsoft gave the seat on OpenAI board\n\nThe surprise decision is said to be due to the growing scrutiny from antitrust regulators on Big Tech's influence over artificial intelligence.\n\nThe move comes after European regulators in June said that they were going to survey Microsoft's rivals about OpenAI's exclusive use of its technology. It shows the increasing pressure on Microsoft, which hopes to tap OpenAI's services to propel its Windows and Copilot AI platforms. Bloomberg News recently reported that the US is opening a separate antitrust investigation into Microsoft's alleged dominance of the rapidly emerging field.\n\nMicrosoft, which also runs the Azure cloud computing service, reportedly faces questions about its other investments in the sphere.\n\nThe FTC also opened a probe into whether Microsoft failed to properly notify the antitrust agencies about its deal with Inflection AI, according to the people. In March, the Redmond, Washington-based software giant agreed to pay the startup $650 million to license its AI software and hired much of Inflection's staff.\n\nOpenAI on Microsoft leaving the board\n\nResponding to Microsoft giving up the board seat, an OpenAI spokesperson told Bloomberg in a statement, \"We're grateful to Microsoft for voicing confidence in the Board and the direction of the company, and we look forward to continuing our successful partnership.\"\n\nMicrosoft took the observer position after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was fired last year by the board and later eventually rehired.Post Altman's rehiring, most of the board members were reshuffled. The new board at OpenAI consists of former Salesforce co-CEO Bret Taylor, former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers, Instacart CEO Fidji Simo, ex-Sony Corp EVP Nicole Seligman, former Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation CEO Dr. Sue Desmond-Hellmann, ex-NSA head Paul Nakasone, and Sam Altman apart from D'Aneglo.\n\nThe TOI Tech Desk is a dedicated team of journalists committed to delivering the latest and most relevant news from the world of technology to readers of The Times of India. TOI Tech Desk's news coverage spans a wide spectrum across gadget launches, gadget reviews, trends, in-depth analysis, exclusive reports and breaking stories that impact technology and the digital universe. {"uri": "8218056673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:30:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:30:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:29:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/microsoft-ditches-openai-board-observer-050715476.html", "title": "Microsoft ditches OpenAI board observer seat amid regulatory scrutiny", "body": "BRUSSELS (Reuters) -Microsoft has ditched the board observer seat at OpenAI that has drawn regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, saying it was not necessary after the AI start-up's governance had improved significantly in the past eight months.\n\niPhone maker Apple had also been expected to take an observer role on OpenAI's board but would not do so, the Financial Times reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of the matter. Apple did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMicrosoft took a non-voting, observer position on OpenAI's board in November last year after OpenAI CEO Sam Altman took back the reins of the company which operates the generative AI chatbot ChatGPT.\n\nThe seat meant it could attend OpenAI's board meetings and access confidential information but had no voting rights on matters including electing or choosing directors.\n\nThe observer seat and Microsoft's more than $10 billion investment in OpenAI have triggered unease among antitrust watchdogs in Europe, Britain and the U.S. over how much control it exerts over OpenAI.\n\nMicrosoft cited OpenAI's new partnerships, innovation and growing customer base since Altman's return to the startup for giving up its observer seat.\n\n\"Over the past eight months we have witnessed significant progress by the newly formed board and are confident in the company's direction. Given all of this we no longer believe our limited role as an observer is necessary,\" it said in a letter to OpenAI dated July 9.\n\nEU antitrust regulators last month said the partnership would not be subjected to the bloc's merger rules because Microsoft does not control OpenAI, but they would instead seek third-party views on the exclusivity clauses in the agreement.\n\nIn contrast, the British and U.S. antitrust watchdogs continue to have concerns as well as questions about Microsoft's influence over OpenAI and the latter's independence.\n\nMicrosoft and OpenAI are increasingly competing to sell AI technology to enterprise customers, aiming to generate revenue and demonstrate their independence to regulators to address antitrust concerns.\n\nAdditionally, Microsoft is expanding its AI offerings on the Azure platform and has hired Inflection's CEO to head its consumer AI division, a move widely interpreted as an effort to diversify beyond OpenAI.\n\n(Reporting by
